text:
5+++++ I love this recipe. I made some healthy substitutions and it turned out yummy for me. I used whole wheat flour, splenda, and apple sauce in lieu of the oil. I also added about 1 tsp of brown sugar and 1/2 tsp of cinnamon as others have recommended. I followed another users recommendation to seperate the whites from the eggs (beated until fluffy) and folded them into the batter as the final step--turned out nice and fluffy. I served these plain with the cinnamon butter recipe. Also, you can freeze left-overs (if any) in plastic baggies to be taken out at a later time to be quickly reheated in the toaster. 5-star plus--thanks for the wonderful recipe!

text:
A well above par recipie, crispy and light. If you have a spare minute beat the egg whites separate, then fold them in at the last, not vital but you will not regret it.

I also doubled the vanilla and sugar, but the waffles seemed a bit bland still, relying on butter/syrup to bring most of the flavor. A good active-yeast recipe will taste better, but are generally more dense.

Also be sure to USE BAKING POWDER, NOT SODA, then the 4 teaspoons called for is perfect, if you put in 4 tsp of soda you'll never have heartburn again...

Bottom line, these waffles are well worth making. Simple, light and almost 5 star good.

text:
This is a great, basic, easy waffle.  My waffle iron sat unused for--literally--10 years.  Wanted to try something new this morning with basic ingredients that I knew I had in the kitchen.  

The first waffle didn't turn out because I didn't use enough batter--my waffle iron needed about 2/3 cup each--but after that they were perfect.

For those new to waffle-making, here is a good tip I have used to know when they are done without having to open the iron constantly to look (which can ruin the waffle if it is still soft)...  It's done when the waffle quits ejecting plumes of steam around the edges of the iron.  (It's also usually done when it quits sticking to the iron.)

Will definitely make these again -- probably tomorrow!

text:
HALF THE CALORIES, NO BRAINER!!  These waffles are good BUT...I made easy changes to make HUGE improvements to the nutritional value.  Instead of 2 eggs I used 3 egg whites and I used skim milk made into buttermilk instead of 2% milk (just add 1-1/2T lemon juice and let sit for 5 minutes). In place of ½ cup of oil I used fat-free vanilla yogurt.  I agree with other reviews that the recipe as written is a little bland so instead of 1 tbsp white sugar I used ¼ cup Splenda.  I also used 2 tsp of vanilla and about a heaping tsp cinnamon.  I can feel GOOD about serving a 195 calorie waffle as opposed to a 400 calorie waffle - especially when my picky husband can't tell the difference!

text:
As is, this is a really good spot on recipe.  Easy to make and enjoyable to eat.  However, with a few modifications it melts in your mouth!  
Here are the modifications that I made and yes, this will be redundant because so many other reviewers have done the same thing, AND with good reason!  Yum Yum!
Sugar changed 2 tablespoon brown sugar AND 2 tablespoon white sugar
vanilla extract changed 1 1/4 teaspoon vanilla extract
Added 1/4 tsp of cinnamon did not want to overpower the flavor of the waffles themselves.  
The other changes I did were on the building...
The eggs and how they are incorporated.. and yes, again this is redundant because sooo many others have said the same thing and it works to make them light and delicious!
seperate the eggs... put the whites in the blender and whip them till they start forming the fluffy whites... then add the yolks on low... then i added the milk, then the vegetable oil allowing to mix before adding the vanilla and all the dry goods (mix them before hand in another bowl).  
This helped produce a light waffle that really melted in my mouth YUM!  I will post a pict later of how they turned out.

text:
These are GREAT waffles.  My kids and husband loved them.  They are nice and light and taste good.  EASY to make.  

About the review that said they have to much baking soda--oops.  The recipe calls for baking POWDER and if you use Rumford brand there is no bad flavor at all (it's healthier too).  Just a heads up for those who might not try the recipe based on that review.  

This is my new waffle recipe.

OMG!!  You do NOT need any oil at all.  Want to know how I know?  I'm a ditz with 5 young children and they are all out of school today chanting "Waffles!  Waffles!" so I am fixing waffles and I accidentally omitted the oil.  I didn't realize it until I wondered why my oil was out on the counter an hour later.  They turned out wonderful!  Omit the oil, save the calories, and save your money.  Have you priced oil lately?!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I have a Belgian waffle maker and always used boxed Aunt Jemima mix as the waffle batter.  Today, I became adventurous by replacing the Aunt Jemima mix with this recipe.  I was careful use baking powder, not soda to the mix.  This was a success!  Good bye Aunt Jemima.  Depending on your sweet tooth, you may want to add another tablespoon of sugar to the mix.  I am never satisfied with just plain waffles.  I like to make either apple cinnamon or banana walnut waffles.  For apple cinnamon waffles, add one cup of apple sauce and 1 table spoon of cinnamon to the mix.  You may want to also add another one or two table spoons of flour to the batter because apple sauce tends to make things runny.  For the banana walnut waffles, place 8 oz of walnuts and two ripe bananas to a food processor and mix until the bananas become a paste.  Add the banana walnut mix to the waffle batter.  Both the apple cinnamon or banana walnut waffles will be tasty and you will amaze your family and neighbors by the wonderful smells from your kitchen.

text:
I didn't want to use a whole half cup of vegetable oil in this recipe, I cut it in half and substituted a quarter cup of my homemade apple butter. Other than that, I followed the recipe exactly. When the batter was mixed, it was quite thin. I did need to add an additional half cup of flour, then it was perfect. The waffles puffed up beautifully and were crispy on the outside and tender on the inside, even with the additional mixing needed to add more flour. GREAT basic waffle recipe. Four and a half stars for me because of the additional needed flour.

text:
WOW!!! This waffle recipe was great. Like others, I doubled the sugar and vanilla extract. I also used butter instead of oil since that was all I had on hand. The first time, I made the recipe without the cinnamon. The second time I made it WITH the cinnamon (like others have suggested) and it just gave it so much more character, if you will. The cinnamon REALLY gave the waffle something special. I used 1t of cinnamon and will always make it with the cinnamon from now on. These waffles are crisp on the outside and thick and soft on the inside. I used a Waring Pro Belgian Waffle Maker (set to 4) for these waffles. This recipe carries itself as is, but it would also serve as a great "base" if you wanted to add blueberries or bananas or something else to the mixture. A+! Thanks for sharing this one!

text:
I've made this twice so far. Once with beaten egg whites (I thought I might as well beat them while waiting for the waffle iron to heat up) and once with the egg beaten normally.  Both were really delicious and crispy.  Beating the whites gave it a very airy crispness, but the recipe really didn't need it.  Following the recipe exactly gave a crispy outside/more tender inside texture that I really loved.  Wonderful recipe!

text:
Excellent recipe that yields a fluffy and delicious waffle.  Like others, I made a few modifications.  First, I doubled the sugar and vanilla and added cinnamon.  Second, I used buttermilk instead of milk (same measurement).  Finally, after beating the eggs until fluffy, I mixed all the wet ingredients together in one bowl and all the dry ingredients together in another, larger bowl.  I then folded the wet ingredients into the dry ingredients in thirds and then let the batter rest for about 20 mins before using.  This recipe yielded 8 Belgian Waffles.  Everyone cleaned their plates and wanted seconds (that almost never happens with my kids).  This one is a keeper.  Thanks!

text:
I've made these several times and have learned that the more I beat the eggs, the lighter and fluffier they are (even up to 5 minutes until they are very stiff, then fold them in). I use olive oil, and have added 2-3 tablespoons of milled flax seed which you can't taste. They are still a little bland, so I'll be trying new things as I go. I think next time I'll substitute half the white flower with whole wheat flour and see how that goes. Very easy recipe, one that I will continue using and improvising with as I go.

text:
These are great waffles!  Crispy on the outside and tender inside.  Even better than the recipe I usually use, which is also very good!  I used half whole wheat flour and skim milk.  Made the batter the night before, put it in the fridge, and in the morning, all I had to do was heat up my waffle iron.  So easy!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I rated this a 5 but I used this as a base recipe and changed it quite a bit to make it more flavorful as suggested. I added 1 tbls white vinegar to the milk and let sit for 5 minutes to "sour"the milk (buttermilkish). I used 1 1/2 cups WW flour, 1/4 cup wheat germ and 1/4 cup blue cornmeal. Then added 1/4 cup applesauce and 1/4 cup oil, 2 packages of splenda, 1 tablespoon brown sugar and lemon zest. I used the other suggestions and separated the eggwhites and folded them in last. I chose to add fresh strawberries I had. Was healthy and so good. My kids loved them.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is perfect!  Waffles come out fluffy inside, crispy outside, and completely delicious.  This waffle has fewer calories than some other recipes, which is why I tried it, and I'm pleased that it has all the flavor of classic waffles.  It's definitely not diet food, but it's about 200 calories less than other recipes I've tried, and is within the calorie range that won't throw my diet completely off if I cut back with other meals throughout the day.

I did "healthy it up" a bit by using applesauce instead of oil, and it worked well, although waffles weren't as crispy.  

Thanks for posting this recipe!  My family begs me to make these waffles every day!

text:
Soooo good! These are wonderful-crispy outside and light and soft inside. I used melted butter instead of oil, 1/2 wheat flour, double sugar and vanilla, and separately whipped egg whites folded in right before cooking. My son was amazed by the "fluffiness!" The flavor was wonderful-and all 4 kids and husband agreed. I also added chopped walnuts to my batter (after I made the kids) and with sliced bananas and maple syrup on top I'm in heaven! I doubled the recipe and will freeze the rest for schoolday breakfasts.

text:
Very good starter recipe. Whisking eggs til frothy definitely lightens up the waffles. I used soy milk and added a scoop of Jay Robb's Vanilla Whey powder to try to add some more protein (and some vanilla flavoring). It didn't add a ton of vanilla flavor but I did get my protein from it. Definitely will keep this recipe. It's easy to make and I always have the ingredients on hand!

text:
Wonderful recipe!  I have to admit I was too lazy to get the hand beater out to beat the eggs (I just whisked them up with a fork really well), but man these waffles were awesome.  They really tasted great and everyone in my household loved them.  What I love is that they don't have a lot of sugar and so they didn't taste terribly sweet like some waffles do. I made a full batch and saved the leftover cooked waffles in the fridge, then popped them in the toaster the next day for breakfast and I believe they were even better crisped up in the toaster the next day! Thanks for submitting this recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good!  I did add extra sugar (quite a bit, maybe 4 T in all) because I'm not a syrup fan.  Probably shouldn't because my kids love syrup and put maple syrup on them!  I've tried MANY recipes, this is a keeper for sure.  I've never thought beating the egg whites separately until fluffy made much of a difference, even though I almost always use a recipe that calls for that.  I like recipes that are slightly sweet and not "eggy" tasting.  This one fits the bill.  The secret if you don't like "soggy" (I don't care either way) is to watch your waffle maker and get to know it.  Don't rely on the light to go off or on.  If you like yours more crispy, and it's still steaming quite a bit, don't open it yet.  You won't want to wait until the steam stops completely, most likely, but lessens.  I'm not sure if the irons are on timers or sensors but just watch for steam amount.  Thanks for a simple, delicious recipe.

text:
great recipe but if you have the time, separate your eggs, mix the yolks in as instructed and beat with the rest of the ingredients. whip the whites in a seperate bowl to a soft peak.  Fold gently into the mixture at the very end.  They will be a lot fluffier.

I made this several times and everyone loved them, but today I decided to add a grated apple, cinnamon and raisins as well as 1/4 cup raw bran.  The kids only noticed the apples and raisins.  

Thank you for this wonderful recipe!

None
text:
I tweaked this just a bit. I’m not terribly fond of using vegetable oil in recipes. I cut out half the vegetable oil, replaced it with melted butter, combined the two and then slowly whisked the fats into the batter to be evenly distributed. The waffles had a nice buttery flavor to them by doing that. I’ve found these freeze well, a godsend for anyone with a busy lifestyle and can be reheated in a toaster like any store bought waffle out there.  These also work well for Belgian Waffle irons too. A great all around waffle recipe.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
As written, it's your basic waffle recipe.  It's quite good on it's own.  It's possible to make them awesome with just a few changes.  One, separate the eggs for sure, beating the whites separately and folding them in last.  I also add one additional Tbs. white sugar, 1 tsp. maple sugar and 1 tsp. vanilla sugar.  Yeah, we like our waffles sweet enough that you can eat them without syrup and we don't even like to pretend waffles are health food!  I get ten waffles in my Calphalon No-Peek iron from one recipe, but I always double it and freeze the extras for toasting.  They're so delicious the kids eat them like toast on the way to school with no butter or syrup necessary.

text:
Fluffy, not too oily, and crisp on the outside.  Helpful hint:  when adding more sugar than the recipe calls for (we like ours sweet), whisk eggs, whisk again with sugar until sugar is dissolved, then add remaining ingredients.  It allows for the sugar to be incorporated so it doesn't cause the batter to stick to the waffle iron. Add a dash of cinnamon and cardamom. My kids don't even know what the flavor is. I have also used 1/2 cup stone-ground whole wheat flour plus 1/4 c. milk. Mmmm...

text:
Ok so after making them the way the recipe was written and then after being disappointed and then reading a lot of reviews I changed a few things and these came out perfect! I used 1/2 cup butter instead of vegetable oil, I think this made them less soggy and more crunchy! I doubled the sugar and the vanilla. I lowered the baking powder down to 2 1/2 teaspoons and a sprinkle of nutmeg and 1/2 tablespoon of cinnamon, you could add less cinnamon, but my kids loooved the cinnamon flavor!

*** I was at my brother's house and he's vegan so he was out of milk. I used almond milk instead of regular milk and wow, they turned out fantastic.. I think I will use almond milk from now on, they seemed to turn out more crunchy, I also added a half teaspoon of baking power up to 3 teaspoons.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Tried this recipe because of the reviews and it was great! The only substitutions I used were whole wheat pastry flour, doubled the vanilla and sugar (also subbed for brown sugar) per suggestions and added in a pinch of cinnamon and cardamom.  The perfect amount of sweetness for eating a waffle by itself. The only tiny issue I have, it's mainly a personal preference, was that the waffles were a tad greasy with the amount of oil, so next time I will try it with a healthier alternative besides just oil (applesauce or yogurt). I didn't have enough time to beat the eggs until fluffy like the recipe states since my beaters were dirty but hand whisking it slightly was all I was able to do. The waffle is fluffy, light and crisps up nicely. Oh, I highly suggest you let these cool on a wire rack, otherwise, they will stay soggy. Letting them cool on the rack lets the outside crisp up nicely. This made 9 waffles for me, using 1/2c measurement and a regular circular waffle iron. The batter is thin when you make it but just pour the batter in a circular motion and you'll have an even batter waffle! Great recipe, thanks!

text:
Great recipe.  Like others, I separated the eggs and folded the whites into the batter.  That is the key to very fluffy and light waffles.  I am making a double-batch right now to freeze so we can eat them on the go during the week.  To freeze: cool waffles completely on a wire rack, then layer on a cookie sheet and freeze a few hours until solid before wrapping in a freezer bag.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a good recipe, but a little on the unhealthy side. To kick up the fiber, I split the flour for 1 cup white/1 cup whole wheat and added 1/4 cup ground flaxseed. Becuase the flavor of the waffles is so bland, I increased the flavor by using 4 tablespoons of Splenda to sweeten and 1 tsp vanilla. Even using ht basic recipe, the batter is a bit thick and leands to a dense waffle, so to lighten the batter, I added an additional 1/2 cup milk.  NOt only did the husband gobble up his waffle, but the kids enjoyed them as well.  Additionally, it is better to mix all the dry ingredients first so that you have a consistent batter and then after mixing in your wet ingredients, let your batter rest to let it fully rise.

text:
I make this recipe almost every weekend. I prep about a dozen waffles and put them in the fridge. I regularly add fruit and mini chocolate chips. Favorite additions include 2 mashed bananas + mini semisweet chocolate chips OR half a can of pumpkin puree and a couple spoonfuls of brown sugar. So easy!!

text:
These turned out so yummy!  I doubled the sugar and vanilla as many suggested and they were really good!  I love this recipe because it doesn't use buttermilk which I never have on hand, and when I buy it specifically for waffles I can only find it in the 1L containers and end up wasting most of the container because I do not use buttermilk for anything else.  Now I will probably make waffles more often since I always have all of these ingredients in the house.  I topped half of my waffle with real maple syrup and the other half with real whipped cream and some fresh strawberries, yum!  I reheated one in the toaster at work the next day and it squished a little but turned out crispy and yummy!  Thanks for the great recipe!

text:
This would get 5 stars but it did need just a little tweaking IMHO...I added 1 tsp cinnamon, I beat egg whites separately and folded in last, doubled sugar to 2 Tb (could use 3 next time), used a little less oil (will try melted butter next time for flavor), and had to add a little milk to make it flow over the waffle iron. I decided to try half whole wheat flour and was pleased with the result. These waffles cooked MUCh faster than most other recipes I have used: they were done in 3 minutes max even on a medium setting. Very light and crisp on the outside, they were not at all chewy or dense. In fact, they were probably the lightest in texture I have ever made. We enjoyed them with butter and real maple syrup this morning. Yum!

Sarah

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/253991.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I read a lot of the reviews saying how bland the waffles were but overall good.  Here is what I did differently:  1) Seperated the eggs and beat the whites until they formed soft peaks.  2) Replaced regular milk with buttermilk, and infused the milk with a split vanilla bean for 10 minutes... Strained vanilla bean and seeds   3) Replaced the vanilla extract with 1 teaspoon vanilla bean paste (hard to find, but some specialty food stores carry it)  4) Add a tablespoon of Best Foods mayo for extra fluffiness!  (I know it sounds weird but it's an old trick!)  5) Fold in egg whites last! With the egg whites, fold in a GOOD drizzle of pure maple syrup.  I topped the waffles with fried chicken, warm maple syrup and powdered sugar!  (My husband wanted to try wings and waffles after seeing it on Diners, Drive Ins, and Dives!) Next time I will make them for breakfast and add some blueberries and slivered almonds!     *** For the holidays, you can make these with pumpkin puree and cut down on the milk and add sweetened condensed milk (infused with a cinnamon stick and vanilla bean), nutmeg, cinnamon, and pumpkin pie spice***

text:
I just bought a mini waffle maker and have been eager to try out a few waffle recipes. Within a span of 3 days I have tried two waffle recipes on this site. This one, and the Classic Waffles Recipe. Both my husband and I agreed that we much prefer the Classic Waffles Recipe. They came out perfect, crispy on the outside, and light and fluffy on the inside. On the other hand, this recipe, Waffles I, came out slightly soggy. I think it might have to do with the dry to wet ingredients ratio. The Classic Waffles Recipe calls for slightly less milk and oil/butter. They just worked out so much better for us. And,it might really just have to do with what brand waffle maker you have. I would try out both and see which one works out best for you!

I used this recipe to christen my new waffle baker.  As suggested by other reviewers, I doubled the sugar and vanilla.  If I try this recipe again, I won't increase the vanilla because I think it adversely affected the flavor and texture (probably because I only had the cheap stuff). I do not understand some of the poor ratings for this recipe. I have been using basically the same recipe for years and it makes the best waffles! The only thing different is the method and that is to whip up the whites separately and then fold them in. This does make them very fluffy. So I may do that from now on to reduce the fat content.

After reading many of the reviews on this recipe, we decided to give it a go using some of the alterations. We subbed out the oil for yogurt, doubled the sugar and vanilla, added cinnamon and nutmeg. text:
This recipe is great! Easy, fast, and the waffles are just the perfect delicious texture. Thought, I warn you to follow the recipe exactly! I have made this recipe a few times, and it seemed strange to mix flour with eggs before adding milk and other wet ingredients so I decided to mix dried and wet ingredients separately and then mix them together. Well, it didn't work: the waffles came out very starchy and bready, nothing like the first few times when I followed the order of mixing the ingredients in the recipe. So I made it again, following the mixing order from the recipe and yes! the waffles are great and yummy again! Moral of the story: stick to the recipe!

text:
Great start to the recipe. Taking ideas from others - Replaced oil with applesauce, substituted 1 cup wheat flour in place of 1 cup white flour and replaced white sugar with brown sugar. Separated whites from yolk     Toppings   
Easy to make homemade whipped cream  (from 121 whipped cream recipe) freeze metal bowl for 15 minutes. Take 1 cup of heavy whipping cream and whisk until fluffy. Add 2 tbsps of sugar and 1 tsp of vanilla extract. Continue whisking until the right consistency--stiff with peaks.

Frozen Organic strawberries and Organic wild boreal blueberries  grown naturally with no pesticides (trader joes)
Empty fruit into sauce pan on medium flame continuously stirring, add 1 tsp of sugar and 1/4 tsp of  salt. Heat and stir until right saucy consistency with smaller than bite size fruit pieces.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fabulous, easy recipe I will use every time. I only had 2% milk so I subbed in 1/2 cup heavy whipping cream to make the 1-3/4 cup called for. I also had to add an extra (approx) 1/3 cup 2% after mixing everything to thin it out. I used 1/4 veg oil and 1/4 cup melted butter. Used one whole tsp pure vanilla. I have a new, Foodnetwork non-stick, 4-slice waffle iron so I did not spray the iron. Set heat to crispy and they were still tender inside. Perfect. My batter made 10 fat waffles. A small dash of cinnamon or any other seasoning (or even chocolate chips or blueberries) would work great with this recipe. Versatile. Husband said they were the best waffles he's ever eaten and my 2 young kids inhaled them. Shared with several friends!

text:
Great recipe. I make it with 1/2 whole wheat flour and 1/2 white flour that i sift. I also add a scoop (about1/4 cup) of flax seed. And to up the flavor I double the vanilla. I'll make a double batch on Sunday and save the leftover batter for a quick, healthy, hot weekday breakfast. Thanks for making my weekday morning a bit less hectic!!!

text:
I ran out of pancake mix, which is what I usually use to make waffles, so I thought I'd try this recipe since it had such good reviews. The taste and texture were awful. Actually, the waffles didn't have much taste at all. The recipe should have called for butter instead of oil, because they had absolutely no flavor. The texture was chewy and didn't have the nice crispy crust like the waffles I make using pancake mix. I added melted butter to the syrup so the waffles would have some flavor so that my husband and son would eat them. Waste of time and ingredients!

text:
Mediocre waffles.  Too much baking powder leaving a sort of metallic odor during cooking and flavor when eating. .  Also not nearly as ethereal as waffles made from beating egg whites separately from the yolks.  My favorite recipe uses the same flour, three eggs separated and beaten separately, half as much fat  twice the salt. They make waffles with a super light interior and nice crunch to the outside.  These had the crunch but the inside was heavy and tasted of baking powder.

text:
Made these for the first time this morning....absolutely delicious!  Family said they were better than a restaurants...I did follow a couple of reviewers advice....added less oil, a bit more sugar, and read that the best way to have crispy waffles but fluffy inside was to not keep lifting the lid....when the steam starts to slow down, that's when they're done....so no need to peek!  Made homemade strawberry sauce from here too, as the perfect compliment...(with whipped cream of course!) Awesome recipe....

This was great! I doubled the recipe. The only thing I did differently was I separated the egg yolks and whites and beat the whites and folded them into the batter. This one is a keeper!!!

text:
Awesome recipe! After reading the reviews doubled the recipe increasing the sugar to 1.5 Tbsp. 2 Tsp. vanilla.  I used 1/2 the oil, 1.5 cups of flour and added 1/4 cup quick cooking oatmeal,(if you double the original recipe as I do 2/3 cup of quick cooking oatmeal)2/3 cup walnuts, pecans and almonds gound fine.  I added 1/3 cup of Trader Joes Powdered Hemp Protein.
Used Xtra Large eggs and also beat the whites separately.  I used 1/2 soy milk and 1/2 coconut milk.  I've also substituted water by 1/2 for lesser calories.  Just blew it right out of the park I tells Ya!!!  These tasted like authentic Belgium waffles! A real hit!!! I need to clarify, so sorry, the nut quantity is for the double recipe.  Please double all previous ingredients to that if you want to attempt my version...didn't mean to confuse people.

text:
This is absolutely the perfect waffle recipe to me.  I originally got it from my old Betty Crocker cookbook and am glad it's posted here so I can print it out instead of getting sticky fingerprints all over my cookbook!  The only change I make is to use melted butter instead of the oil, or use half oil, half butter.  I cook them until the waffle iron stops steaming so they are crisp on the outside and light and airy inside.  They hold up to any syrup without getting soggy or limp.  They are just perfect and my family begs me to make them on weekends.  We love them with syrup or fresh fruit or blueberry compote.

I just made these with my girls and it was very easy to make. I had never tried making waffles before and I have to say I am very happy with this recipe. text:
Not bad at all!  I added a teaspoon of cinnamon as others did, but next time I'll also take the suggestions and add a little more vanilla and sugar.  These freeze great and fit right in the toaster for an easy breakfast.  Love it!  No more store-bought frozen waffles!  Also, try substituting brown sugar for half of the white sugar... AMAZING!!  UPDATE (5/31/12):  I have made this recipe numerous times since my initial review and I can say I am done looking for a perfect waffle recipe, this is it!  I continue to add cinnamon to the batter, but I also double the salt, vanilla & sugar.  These cook up beautifully... I make a double or triple batch when I cook these and freeze a bunch of them.  They heat up perfect in the toaster for a fast morning breakfast.  A definite winner!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were allright. A little cakey, but good nonetheless. I was gifted with a Belgian waffle iron for Christmas. Looking for a basic waffle recipe to try out on my new gadget, I stumbled upon OneShy's posting on here. 




Although my hubby and I thought these were good, we both feel I should continue my search for a waffle recipe that better suits us. Thanks to top reviewer fxer, I doubled the sugar / vanilla. I'm glad I did 
because these were just sweet enough for us (without doubling these two ingredients, our waffles likely would have been too bland). I did not, however, beat my egg whites / yolks separately. One thing to note: The user's manual that came with my waffle iron includes a few waffle recipes, one of them a basic one. My hubby and I both noticed that the basic batter recipe does NOT call for eggs (nor do any of the other recipes - they all build off the basic recipe). I'm led to believe that the addition of eggs in OneShy's recipe gave our waffles the texture we didn't care for. My verdict? Overall, this is a nice, basic waffle recipe, but there are others out there I'd rather try. Thanks anyways OneShyOfABunch! :-)

userID:

Display Name:
HappyJoy
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great basic waffle recipe! Very light and fluffy. It also makes a perfect base recipe for customizing. I made it following the recipe the first time, and then played with it a second time. I used whole wheat flour, and substituted 1/4 cup applesauce for 1/4 cup of the oil. I also doubled the vanilla, added another teaspoon of sugar, and added a tablespoon of cinnamon. To combat the heaviness of the whole wheat flour I beat the egg whites separately and folded them in at the end. The result was a hearty and delicious waffle that was still light and moist! I loved the added flavor and texture, so I made a triple batch today and froze them.

As it is written the recipe is good but it could be better.  The second time I made this I made it more healthy and in my opinion that makes it better.  I cut the oil to 1/4 cup and added 1/4 of applesauce.  I also added 1/2 tsp. cinnamon and 2 Tbs. of ground flax seed (this provides omega 3's).  Also, these taste better well cooked until crispy.

text:
I have been looking for a recipe for waffles for a long time, without having to separate the eggs and whip the egg whites.  I just wanted something easy.  I did follow other reviewers hints and double the sugar and vanilla.  I don't think I will do that next time, a little on the sweet side for me.  I know that it will be perfect written as is the next time.  I served these this morning with Sauteed Apples from this site by 356, and I knew I was in food heaven.  I will freeze the extra waffles I made and toast for a quick breakfast.   Since I was on a roll this morning, I decided to mix up another batch, BUT, just mixed the dry and ingredients together.  I put these in a tightly sealed jar and everything will be ready the next time I make waffles so as to save some time.  These were so light and fluffy.  No more boxed mix for me, way too expensive now a days and it doesn't even compare to how delicious these are.  Thanks a bunch Oneshyofabunch!!!  Love the recipe!!

text:
A great waffle recipe for us.  It was easy and tasty.  The kids liked it with a little syrup.  My husband and I enjoyed them straight up - no butter or anything.  We did, however, add some chocolate chips, so I'm sure that helped!  The changes I made were minor and as follows: 1 cup whole wheat flour and 1 cup white flour; 1 tsp vanilla; 2 tbsp cinnamon sugar.  Once the batter was in the belgian waffle maker, I sprinkled chocolate chips on top.  I left them in a little extra long to get them crispier since that's how I like them.

userID:
2615693
Display Name:
brit
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Before I found this, I was using the recipe on the Bisquick box. Bleah.

I made some modifications to this recipe. I used whole-wheat graham flour, liquid egg whites, powdered nonfat milk, kosher salt, and Sugar in the Raw (cane sugar.) I used 2.5 tablespoons of cane sugar, since the graham flour is a little bitter and cane sugar isn't quite the same as white. The result is tasty, delicious, and uber-healthy. :D Top them with some (homemade) cinnamon applesauce and you'll be in breakfast heaven.

I didn't stick the leftover batter in the fridge. Instead, I used it all at once and put a batch of waffles in the freezer. During the week I can just pop a couple waffles in the toaster and go. Yay, freezerwaffles!

text:
Very good! I had some buttermilk I wanted to use up, so I used that instead of regular, I also cut the baking powder in half and doubled the sugar and vanilla.  They were very good. Next time I may increase the sugar and vanilla even more, 1 1/2 teaspoon vanilla, and 3 tablespoons of sugar.  I think that would make them just perfect! Oh, almost forgot. I made a batch with chocolate chips and they were incredible as well! 9/22, I made again only a lower cal version, applesause instead of oil, skim milk, egg beaters.  Blah!  No flavor at all what so ever.  So my kids would eat them I put a ton of butter, syrup, and powdered sugar on them to try and hide the flavorless mess I made.  I luv these waffles, and I'll make again, just not the low cal way.

text:
Best waffles I've ever had, especially given how easy they are!  I followed other's advice and doubled the vanilla and sugar, and added 1 tsp cinnamon, and I sifted all the dry ingredients together. Also I separated the egg whites, beat them, then folded them in the mixture last.  I  also used vanilla paste (Trader Joe's) instead of regular vanilla syrup.  Don't open the waffle maker until the steam stops!  Finished everything off with some fresh sliced strawberries and powdered sugar.

text:
We found the recipe as is, a little bland.  Therefore, I made a few changes:
- double the sugar (2 Tablespoons)
- double the vanilla (2 teaspoons)
- added another egg white
- 1/8 cup of maple syrup     
- couple dashes of cinnamon

This is now a breakfast, and sometimes dinner, favorite.  We love to top it off with Strawberries & whipped cream!

text:
I've made waffles dozens of times in the past year and love this recipe! These are my couple tips I've found. First, don't do only oil! Gives them absolutely NO taste. Seriously. Sub in a few tablespoons of melted butter instead and then add a capful of oil to still get them crispy! 

Second,  I like the waffle iron on a higher setting to get the waffles crispy. I would serve off the iron as they do go soft fairly fast.

None
text:
I've been using this recipe for about a year now and it is always a hit. I have always followed it without any alterations and the waffles come out slightly lacking in flavor, but excellent when it comes to texture. I use real maple syrup and once it's on, the lack of flavor isn't an issue. I shoild also add that I sift all of the dry ingredients into a large bowl before adding the wet ingredients. 

I read the reviews and saw that people suggested adding cinnamon (1tsp.) and more vanilla (1 tsp.) to increase the taste. I tried it tonight and wow! They were delicious! My kids loved them too. I also added just a pinch of nutmeg as well and that flavor came through as well. With the alterations, I can use less syrup and still get an amazing taste.

I have been searching for a good waffle recipe for my new waffle iron, and this one is THE one! They cooked perfectly and my family loved them. I especially like that I can make a big batch and keep the extra batter in the refrigerator all week for an easy, make-your-own breakfast all week long. I made the batter in my blender and stored the extra  in the jar. Anyone who wants waffles just pulls it from the fridge, gives it a quick whirl and pours the batter into the hot griddle. Superb!

I added a Tbs of malt (malted milk) because that is the trick I learned years ago from Waffle House that makes them smell and sort of taste like cookies. But this was the perfect texture, which is extremely important to me, as well as the perfect blend of ingredients and their proportions. SOOO thrilled that I found this recipe. Thank you so much.

text:
Great recipe with ingredients around the house. I agree you should separate and and beat the egg whites then fold in at the end.  Fluffier batter.  Also substituted 1 tbsp butter with 1/4 cup yogurt for part of oil, and added more vanilla than recipe called for (or use vanilla yogurt). Came out great. We often freeze extras (layer with wax paper and place in ziplock bag) for easy toasted breakfast during the week.

Delicious as is, but the second batch I doubled and tweeked. I replaced the oil with pureed peach cups (2) and 1.5 teaspoons vanilla. Best waffles ever!
*Update* Best waffles ever. Between batches, batter doubles. Added 2 T melted butter and pureed peaches to triple batch. Fabulous. *Update* Replace oil/butter with two ripe bananas thrown in while beating the eggs. Ultra creamy texture without banana flavor.

text:
After skimming a few reviews, I seperated my egg whites, whipped them, & folded in at the end; doubled the white sugar, and tripled the vanilla (because my family and I really LOVE vanilla).  These came out so delicious I won't try another recipe!  First time using the waffle iron too! Highly recommend.  No leftovers.  Definitely serve hot! I like melted butter, powdered sugar, and a little whipped cream.

text:
2.9.15 ... https://www.allrecipes.com/recipe/22180/waffles-i/ ... 'Pretty much followed the recipe.  :o  :D  As suggested by a review, subbed with melted butter - well, half melted butter, half oil - & I decreased it to 1/4c - so 2T each.  Next time, I'll go for all melted butter.  'Didn't feel like opening a bag of flour so the last few Ts of flour were whole wheat.  I added 3/4t imitation vanilla to give a creamy flavor vs vanilla (which I am sincerely in love with both).  I was told by S that these were better than the previous recipe (Waffles II by RAZZ_BRRY_JAM), which was years ago.  Hmmmm.  E didn't say anything, but had three.  :)  These are crispy without being hard.  (It's happened.)  Tender inside.  Note:  They'll stick if not greased well (duh), but also if it's not preheated.  'Done when steaming nearly ceases.  This made 11 waffles on my two-waffles-per-batch maker.

None
text:
Good recipe with the following tweaks:

-  Added 1/2 TB sugar and 1 tsp cinnamon
-  Whisked egg whites until very fluffy then folded them into the mixed batter at the end

The result were waffles that were very crisp but light.  Certainly there are other recipes that add butter and loads of sugar, and therefore calories, but I wanted a more healthy option and this one was perfect.  It made about 12 3"x3" waffles, eight of which are now frozen to be reheated for my daughter.  

All around a very good recipe and one that isn't overly loaded with calorie bloat.  I will make them again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe. I saw the review of FXER and applied what they did. 
Folding the egg whites made the batter and ultimately the waffle light and fluffy.
I also changed the sugar. I used 3 1/2 - 4 tablespoons of sugar. 
I also changed the vanilla extract.  I used 1 Teaspoon (I let it overflow just a drop or two ??)
I mixed the ingredients like I make chocolate chip cookies :
-  I mixed the egg yolks with the sugar. 
- Then, I added the milk, then the oil. Please note that I used Extra light virgin olive oil.
- I blended it just for a minute. 
- I had sifted the dry ingredients then Added the dry ingredients to the egg/sugar mixture.  
I mixed it just until it was smooth. It seemed a little thick,so I added maybe 2tspns of milk. You decide. 
Then I beat the egg whites and folded them in. 
Family said it was Great !

Excellent recipe. I did as other reviewers suggested and doubled the sugar and vanilla, and added a sprinkling of cinnamon. This was a hit with the family. this will be my go to recipe.

I found this recipe after I couldn't find my wife's recipe. Was not impressed. A good waffle needs to stand on its own without butter and syrup. The waffle and the batter taste like vegetable oil. It's not very sweet at all. I had to add extra sugar so I couldn't only taste the oil. Butter would be a better substitute for the oil, or at least reducing the amount of oil dramatically and adding butter in its place.

text:
This recipe is my kids' favorite.  I, too, removed on whole egg and added a few egg whites.  I make these on school days, so I want the kid to have a little more protein to help keep them full until lunchtime.  I add bittersweet chips for one kid and vanilla chips for another.  The waffles are light, fluffy, and crispy on the outside.  I don't make the mix ahead of time, but I do prepare all of the dry ingredients the night before.  I just add the wet ingredients in the morning, which makes things just a little faster and easier on hectic school mornings.

country:

text:
I loved this crispy, light waffle!  Like others, I made substitutions. I used two ripe bananas and reduced the oil to 1/3 cup. For a crispy waffle,  the oil cannot be omitted. I increased vanilla to 2 teaspoon (to give it the carnival flavor) and I added 1/2 teaspoon cinnamon. My husband said, "Nailed it!" It's far superior to a box mix, and every bit as easy.

text:
My family gobbled these up! The two things I did different was 1) I made this in my blender and 2) I soured the milk with 2 TBSP of vinegar. In my blender, I beat the eggs until they were frothy, then added the rest of the wet ingredients, combined, and then added the dry. Used the blender spout to pour the batter into my waffle maker. Easy peasy and delicious!

text:
Great recipe. I've made it as written and as a healthier variation(decreasing the white  flour and adding whole wheat flour and wheat germ to equal amount decreased). I've used eggs straight out of the fridge(usually use room temperature as they beat up fluffier), didn't seperate the eggs, ever, and have never had an issue. I've also used up milk and cream that were past date. I always double the vanilla.
This recipe has never failed.

text:
This recipe is awesome, but I tweak every recipe I find.  :)  I beat the eggs with an immersion blender for several minutes before folding into the batter (they became almost medium peak like egg whites) and the waffles were crispier than when I made a similar recipe that called for separating the egg whites.  I stirred a teaspoon of lemon juice into the milk for "buttermilk" waffles.  Also, I added double the vanilla and a heaping tablespoon of malted milk powder.  Easy and yummy!

VAISHALI

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674152.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
If you are looking for a waffle recipe that leads to a nicely crisped surface on the outside while having a soft fluffy interior, this is the one! Anxious to try out my brand new waffle-maker, I picked this recipe. These are the very first waffles I have ever made. The first one turned out nice but was too soft. Starting with the second one, I let the waffles cook to a dark-golden brown. That made the end result perfect - lovely crispness over a tender, fluffy softness! I used the recipe almost exactly the way it is, except for a little less oil, some cinnamon and folding in beaten egg-whites in the end, as suggested by another reviewer. Great results. Next I will try this with whole wheat flour.

text:
I made this recipe tonight for my family and it was a Huge Hit! Everyone loved these waffles! I modified the recipe to make ten servings. I made a few adjustments to this great recipe. I separated the egg whites from the yolks. I whipped the whites until stiff. I added all wet ingredients withe the dry and stirred until lump free then folded in the stiff egg whites. I baked according to directions and My Waffles came out Great! If you are looking for a Great waffle recipe this is the One! Hope you enjoy the recipe as much as our family did!

text:
I hate rating on a recipe I made changes on, but here it is.  I followed other reviewers recommendations and whipped the egg whites and doubled the sugar, vanilla and cinnamon.  I also reduced the oil by half and added a pinch of cloves and a dash of pumpkin spice.  The waffles were light and crispy and had a hint of spice.  The family loved it, will make again.  Thank you for a good recipe.

Edit:  made it again, this time as is, with a little extra vanilla.  It was excellent, fluffy on the inside, crispy on the outside and they freeze so well.  I gave it 5 stars, excellent basic waffle.

Second edit:  I now just put all the ingredients, liquids first, in my Vitamix and mix. Done! I make double batches and freeze. Kids the put in toaster when ready to eat it.

text:
The best waffle recipe I have found to date.  Have adapted to our own preferences and according to my kiddos "the best waffles ever".  If you want a crispy waffle, then try using virgin, unrefined coconut oil instead of vegetable oil.  Also we prefer buttermilk waffles so I will add just a bit of regular milk so thin out the batter.  Once you have the basic mix together, you then add any fruits, nuts, berries, or chocolate chips.  Such a hit for breakfast!

userID:
1389869
Display Name:
SPARKLER8666
isPro:
False
followersCount:
10

96

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tried this recipe to use batter thru the week instead of cooking up all the batter & freezing the extra waffles. 
I disagree with whipping the white separately to create a lighter airier product. These waffles are exactly what I want; a little dense, creamy & soft in the middle, a little crisp on the exterior, lots of flavor & a little chew. If you want light waffles, then go ahead. But I want my waffle to stick to my ribs, not need a lot of sweet syrup, but satisfy my appetite (not tempt me to eat more.)
Modifications: I used half whole wheat white & half white flour & added about 1/2 tsp of yeast per another reviewer to give it that yeasty flavor. I also used melted butter rather than oil, & Splenda Brown instead of white sugar for more flavor. Plus I used the classic method of combining all the wet & dry ingredients first (except I crumbled and mixed the Splenda with the wet to dissolve it) then poured the wet in a well in the dry. I did not "beat" but gently incorporated the two with a rubber spatula & broke up big lumps with a whisk (not beating, just mashing out lumps.) Tiny lumps bake out.
Laid plastic on batter & used it 1, 3, & 6 days later. Did NOT stir the bubbles out; they made it better! Day 6 the top was grey like sourdough starter so I wondered if my yeast hurt it. But it tasted wonderful! (Also added chopped walnuts once b4 closing the waffle iron; yum!) 
Topped it with 1/2 tsp butter & 1 tsp homemade jam or fresh berries mixed with a little jam or karo. :)

None
text:
I made a healthier version of this recipe for a great birthday breakfast with some girlfriends. I beat everything except the eggs together in a bowl. I did substitute the vegetable oil for greek yogurt, added in 2 tbls of ground flax seed, a dash of cinnamon and a bit more milk so the batter wasn't too thick. I then beat 4 egg whites (instead of 2 whole eggs) until stiff peaks formed and folded them into the batter. I covered it and put in the fridge overnight and the batter was ready for the next morning. They were crispy on the outside and moist and soft on the inside. Made me felt a little less guilty once I covered it with butter and syrup!

country:
None
text:
These were wonderful, in texture and flavor and workability while cooking. I used my Belgian flip iron, and they turned out perfectly: golden brown and crisp outside, soft and moist inside. The only problem I had -- and I'm not deducting stars, because more than likely it was totally my fault -- is that the batter, sitting in the fridge, just about doubled in size and did a nice, slow explosion that required more cleanup time than prep and cook time. It's a REALLY thick batter, and REALLY has a lot of baking powder, so it's volatile to begin with. My mistake, but I'd do it again in a larger bowl that can contain the beast, was using honey instead of sugar -- and honey is acid and a reactive with bicarb. A real crowd please.

text:
Very good and fast basic waffle recipe. I did not separate the eggs and they came out delicious. Obviously, if you make the other kind of waffles with yeast and let it sit overnight it will taste more malty like a Belgian waffle, but when you're too lazy or hungry to do that much work, this is a perfect weekend morning stand-in. I'd say they were about 75% as good as the ones that require all the work, with very little work. So maybe I'll stick to this recipe for my go-to waffle recipe and leave the other one for special occasions only. :)

text:
I liked this recipe, but tweeked it a little. I did as suggested in other recipes and added 1 tbsp brown sugar, and cinnamon and nutmeg.  I also subsituted the white flour to 1 c. Whole wheat flour and 1 c. spelt flour, also I replaced the oil with applesauce.  And I put 1c. of milk and 3/4 c. plain yogurt.  They came out perfect.  I have a very good waffle make, so if your waffles stick you may want to add oil to your recipe.

text:
Absolutely DELICIOUS!!!  I doubled the amounts of both the sugar and the vanilla, and the result was a sweet, tasty waffle.  Be sure to mix the batter in a blender--you won't regret it. It's so light and fluffy that it's worth the hassle of washing the blender afterwards! This makes a ton. I doubled it, and had WAAAAY more than my family of 5 could eat!  Next time I'll be adding cinnamon and nutmeg and serving with apple cider syrup for a perfectly spicy autumn breakfast!

text:
Good basic recipe - simple ingredients and allows for modifications to suite individual tastes. I used yogurt instead of oil, added 1 tsp of brown sugar, a total of 2 tsp sugar & 1 tsp cinnamon. Served with blueberries, bananas, walnuts and a little bit of syrup. Family loved them! I like my waffles a little sweet because I prefer them with a little bit of butter & no syrup - so next time I may add more sugar. Leftovers were placed in ziplock and in fridge to toast during the week! Keeper. Thanks.

text:
I've made this recipe both as is, and with some modifications. As is - I have to say, it's pretty bland. The texture is great but there's just no flavor. The 3 star rating is for the recipe as is. I replaced the vegetable oil with melted butter, added a pinch more salt, doubled the sugar & vanilla, and used buttermilk instead of regular milk. I also whipped the egg whites separately and folded them into the batter at the end. With these changes, this could be a 5 star recipe.

I dont understand all the good reviews. These were ok, no flavor to speak of. And i followed recipe exactly. Very bland. I prefer a good pre-made mix to this. If you make these I recommend using extra sugar and vanilla. I sauteed chopped apples in butter cinnamon and sugar and used that as a topping, along with butter and a little maple syrup, THEN, they had flavor.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After searching for a waffle recipe to make for my daughter and her sleep over friends, I found this one. I'm a "Mister Mom" in the kitchen and made these with minimal effort. The only difference with following this recipe was, I have grown accustomed to following the rules of mixing dry and wet ingredients, so i mixed and sifted all the dry, mixed all the liquid and lightly beat them, then added the wet to the dry. They were a little bland so i added more vanilla, cinnamon and sugar, to taste. They were great w the addition of the blueberry sauce recipe(i found here also) and finished w whip cream. I won't eat them regularly, but they were a nice weekend treat.

text:
Pretty good, but not great.  The waffles weren't crispy - and it did not seem that any additional cooking would help.  I did beat the egg white separately then fold in at the end.  I'm not sure if this affected the crispness.  Additionally, as the batter sat while the first waffle cooked, it seemed to deflate and the second waffle was even soggier.  I did use about 1/3 whole wheat flour.  I'm not sure what exact effect that had, but next time I would use a couple teaspoons or so of orange juice substituted for some of the milk to cut the strong whole wheat flavor.

text:
As others I also used whole wheat flour, applesauce in lieu of oil and splenda instead of the sugar.  I did beat the egg whites separately and folded in at the end. What a fantastic waffle!!  Made the batter the night before and they were just wonderful when I made them the next morning.  Left over waffles freeze very well and come out very nice after a few minutes in the toaster.  Thanks for the recipe :)

text:
Very delicious! When I say that I followed the ingredients exactly, I did...I was in a rush to make breakfast for the in-laws, and didn't even look for suggestions in the reviews (which I always do). I didn't even beat the eggs, just threw all ingredients into a big bowl, mixed by hand and put them on the waffle maker.  My only complaint is that the batter is thin and flows out of the maker each time you make a waffle.  A bit messy, but the result is fluffy, crispy, and chewy.  The taste is akin to a waffle cone.  Delicious with fruit, butter, and syrup!

text:
Unbelievable! I'll never make any others. I followed the advice of another review and put all the ingredients in the blender (dry first, wet second). I used 2 Tablespoons brown sugar as substitute for white, I used 2 teaspoons vanilla, and 3 large (not extra large) eggs.  I blended it on high for 4-5 minutes. My family and a visiter all proclaimed them on par with the ones from the fancy breakfast restaurants. I do have flipover waffle maker (not sure if that makes any difference) :)

text:
I am always looking how to make a recipe more healthy so here are my revisions:
I used 1 cup of my own ground wheat berries and 1 cup of whole wheat pastry flour.  I used 1 stick of real butter (melted), and I used coconut milk instead of milk.  I used 4 T honey to sweeten and the rest of the recipe I kept the same.  My family loved these waffles!

I beat the egg whites seperatly then added the yolks, then all the rest of the wet ingredients. Then I mixed up all the dry and added the wet to the dry gradually. Based on other reviews I increased the vanilla to 1 teaspoon and the sugar to 2 tablespoons. Could use even more vanilla. The batter is a thin, next time I would decrease the milk a little. Overall these waffles are light and very tender. Will make again

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I'm diabetic and can *barely* tolerate carbs in the morning at all since I am pregnant. However, I've been having a waffle craving recently so I made these for lunch instead and they fit the bill perfectly. This is a great from-scratch recipe! It's hard to find a whole wheat recipe that turns out light and fluffy. I used whole wheat flour instead of white flour, buttermilk instead of milk, melted margarine instead of oil, increased the sugar to 1 1/2 T and doubled the vanilla; then threw everything into the blender. It's just my husband and I at home this weekend so this made WAY more than we could eat, so I froze the rest for my son to toast for breakfasts. He'll be happy. :)

Great tasting. Although I made these quickly this morning and would suggest that you not make them in ingredient order. I was sleepy and did and ended up with pockets of baking powder. I am a seasoned cook, but my sleepy eyes led me to think there was a reason for the ingredient order and didn't asses the situation.  All that to say mix dry ingredients apart for wet ingredients and then add to wet ingredients.  Otherwise delicious.

text:
Made this recipe last weekend and come Friday, the family is still raving about them!  I used self-rising flour instead of the flour-baking powder-salt combo, and probably could've added about 2 more teaspoons baking powder to make them rise a bit more. Loved the tip to store leftover baked waffles between paper towels to absorb the moisture & keep them from sticking together.   They re-heated beautifully in the toaster oven after letting them come to room temp (stored in a gallon-sized Zip-loc bag to keep them from drying out).  We will have these often!

luv2bake

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great classic waffle recipe.    I liked the suggestion of whipping the egg whites, which truly makes the waffles crispy on the outside and moist on the inside.  Three other changes that I made were:  1.  Add 1/4 c. sugar - the extra sugar made my girls want to eat the waffles without the syrup.  2.  Used whole wheat pastry flour - it's white and fine, yet has the extra fiber that our family needs.  3.  Reduced the flour to 1-3/4 C and added 1/4 c. Malted Barley Flour.  This is a key ingredient in waffles and made them taste just like the ones you make at the Marriott Residence Inn or Fairfield Inn - I think it's the Carbon brand of waffle mix.  Anyway, the recipe is great and I've even hand-written the recipe in my recipe book.  Thanks for sharing this!

Very good!  Have already made it twice today and plan on freezing extras.  For the first batch, I used 2 cups wheat flour instead of the all purpose flour and the waffles had a more grainy texture that I wasn't too fond of.  The second batch, I compromised and used 1 cup all purpose flour and 1 cup wheat flour - perfect! text:
This was my first time making homemade waffles and this recipe is soooo incredibly easy and they turned out awesome.  I used whole wheat flour, doubled the vanilla and added a little cinnamon.  Half way through making them I saw 2 bananas that were going bad so I mashed them up and made banana waffles.  Turned out pretty good, they don't get as crispy on the outside and turn a little dark. They taste like banana bread though!  I make these ahead of time and freeze them for my 2 year old so she doesn't care what they look like, she just knows they taste good :) Edited: I sub applesauce for the oil, egg whites in place of the egg. Still tastes great and way less calories.

text:
If you've ruined breakfast by screwing up the waffles ( I sound like an opening for a promo  :), this is a fail safe recipe. I wasn't paying attention, (multi-tasking on everything but preparing breakfast), to the order nor the proper combination of ingredients and dumped them altogether into a bowl ...I looked into the mess I had made and pulled out my mini-hand mixer that I use to whip heavy cream into whip cream and blended it together for 2-3 min., until it was creamy. To add to this mess, I threw in an equal amt of almond extract matching the vanilla. These waffles turned out perfect, light and fluffy, melted in your mouth, can't wait to cook the rest of the batch; I froze half the batter. I sprinkled some powdered sugar on top and poured maple syrup on top for an added sugar high, love this recipe...a real winner!

My old waffle recipe had me jumping through "special" steps in order to make the "perfect" waffle.  I got tired of it taking so long to put together and came on here to find a different recipe. Super Delicious recipe! I used SELF rising flour and omitted the salt & baking powder, and it worked perfectly! I also beat my egg whites seperately and folded them in last. Based on other reviews I used 1 tsp. vanilla and 2 Tbls. sugar. I folded in 1 cup of frozen blueberries at the very end and cooked in my waffle maker for 5 minutes. AWESOME! My waffle maker made 8 waffles using this recipe. This one is a keeper and will be my regular waffle recipe. Super easy and superb! If you add in blueberries-leave them frozen. They make for a really great Blueberry waffle!

text:
I used whole wheat flour and doubled the vanilla.  They were very light and fluffy although I did have a little trouble with them sticking and ended up using a lot of oil on the pan.  Depending on your waffel iron it may not be good for it to use a non-stick spray, mine says not too.  The propellant can damage the non stick coating so I use vegtable oil and a brush to apply it.

This was an excellent recipe.  The reason I only gave it 3 stars is that the recipe said you could keep the batter in the fridge for up to a week. It was so runny it ran out of the iron and onto the counter.  Not a good recipe to keep in the fridge!!!

text:
We were out of Bisquick, so I started searching this site and went with this recipe because of the huge number of positive reviews. We had them for dinner tonight and they were really good! (I always hated Bisquick ones - taste like biscuits with syrup...). I used 2 1/2 tbsp white sugar and 2 tsp vanilla. I didn't change anything else, ingredient-wise. I did beat the whites separately and folded them in at the end and we did sprinkle shredded cheddar cheese on half of them (after pouring batter into the waffle iron). My husband grew up with cheddar cheese waffles. We used a Mickey Mouse iron and I got about 15 waffles with this recipe. The whole family wolfed them down! I am going to continue to play around with it and try different flavors, but it is already saved in my box.  Thanks.

Great recipes!  Thanks to the suggestions of other reviewers, I:

1. Doubled the sugar and vanilla
2. Beat the egg whites and yolks separately.  I folded in the fluffy egg whites and the waffles came out nice and fluffy.
3. I used the measuring scoop that came with waffle maker (3/4 cup) and this was perfect.

I want to add cinnamon next time.

Great waffles!

text:
Great waffle recipe!  Quick and easy to make, delicious to eat.  I used brown sugar and added some ginger, nutmeg, and cloves to give the waffles a gingerbread flavor and served them with pumpkin butter.  My husband loved them.  Since this recipe basically calls for just mixing all of the ingredients together, i used my big 4 cup measuring cup to measure out all of the liquids and mix them up first, then I just measured the dry ingredients right into the measuring cup and beat them in with a whisk.  I have fewer dishes and I used the measuring cup to just pour the batter right onto the waffle iron!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been looking for a waffle recipe that I could make ahead of time and would keep for a few days to use when I go camping.  Also during the week I can use just enough batter to make 2-3 waffles (belgian type) and put the rest in the frig for the next day.  Tried several recipes, including several yeast recipes, but nothing was as light and crispy as this one.  (The waffles actually taste better if the batter sits for a day!) Doubled the sugar and the vanilla and used butter instead of oil.  **NOTE: During our last camping trip the power went out and we couldn't use the waffle maker so we thinned out the batter with a little water and made crepes -- came out really good!

text:
These are not the ultimate waffles ever, but, this is a nice base recipe. I decreased the baking powder to 1 tsp and increased the sugar to 1/4 cup. Will add some more baking powder back in next time. I may add a touch more sugar next time since I have a husband that doesn't like syrup on waffles. These were fluffy on the inside and crispy on the outside. This made a total of 12 waffles (3 sheets) on my waffle iron. I averaged them sitting in the iron about 4 minutes if that helps anyone. My first batch I kept opening and closing the lid which didn't help matters. The nice thing about this recipe is that I know exactly what I am feeding my children and it sure isn't store bought waffles filled with preservatives. Thank you for sharing Ultra B.

text:
I was looking for a lower-fat/less oil waffle recipe. Could not find one yet - so I tried this one. They were very good. Consistency was great. Had good flavor-the vanilla  and sugar amount was just right, for us. Made up fluffy and browned nicely at 3 minutes, on my pre-heated waffle maker. I have made waffles many different ways-from scratch and from prepared mixes. Two, eleven year olds, said "these are the best you ever made"!  And, I LOVED using only the one bowl method of this recipe. It was more convienient and less mess to clean up. Until I find a "healthier" version, I definitely will use this recipe's version. 
Thank you, Ultra B, for sharing.

userID:
1166377
Display Name:
Colette Castro
isPro:

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2137295.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First time using a waffle iron. I saw the “can use whole wheat flour” in the preface, so I used 1- 1/4 cup of flour, 2/3 cup ground quick oats (ground in my coffee bean grinder), and the rest ground flax to make up the full 2 cups. I realized I had no milk, so I used 1/2 cup half and half (don’t judge! Lol) some unsweetened almond milk and two big “globs” of homemade unsweetened plain Greek style yogurt, probably 3-4 Tbsps. The rest as is, except I put all the dry ingredients together and the wet in a 2cup measuring cup. I whipped the wet with a fork and then poured it into the dry. Took several batches to figure out  a little less than 1/3 cup fills the corners but does not overflow the sides. Hubby likes a little softer 2 1/2  to 3 minutes and I like them closer to 3 1/2 to 4 minutes cook time... but then again I like my toast dark .

 I only used 2tsp of baking powder instead of 4. Mine still came out very fluffy.

text:
Ok. I did not make this exactly as stated because I have a kid who’s allergic to dairy, didn’t have enough oil, and I wanted to add protein. But I’m giving 5 stars because it adapted beautifully, and everybody had multiple servings. My adjustments were as follows: subbed almond milk, replaced some of flour (less than half) with a mixture of whole wheat and almond flour, subbed half (or more) oil with applesauce. They were still light and fluffy and delicious.

text:
These waffles turned out fantastic! I halved the recipe at first just to try it out. I let my stand mixer whip up my egg until I had the other ingredients ready, add, mix & pour! Super simple & easy to adjust the liquid to your desired consistency. I like crispy waffles, my husband likes them a bit softer & this was easy to do both.  On my second round, I added blueberries on top of my batter in the waffle iron for perfect distribution & they were fantastic.  I even cut the leftover waffles in half & reheated in the toaster & everyone loved them.  Great recipe!

Great mix that goes together fast and tastes as almost as good as the expense mix we've been buying. text:
Tastes great! I made the batter exactly as the recipe instructed and my wife and kids loved it, as did I. I used a waffle iron that makes the waffle in the shape of Olaf from Frozen so leaving the batter cooking for three minutes or more nearly burned it because of the skinny twig arms. I had to go just under three minutes and they came out perfect. Made the left over batter about six days later and it definitely holds up for six days.

Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

helpfulCount:
0
userID:
3961642
Display Name:
Amanda Chisholm
isPro:
False
followersCount:
4
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
35
favoritesCount:
343
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1360000.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are fantastic and my go-to recipe for waffles! I make my own adjustments for my family's  tastes and needs, as everyone does, and they're perfect every time! Adjustments I made were to substitute Splenda for sugar and double it, use half whole wheat flour and half AP, use half butter and half coconut oil, and a splash of maple extract and a dash of cinnamon. I did end up increasing the milk, due to ww flour requires more, but I just added until I got the right consistency. The eggs I just whipped, not separated, in my mixer until they were fluffy, then dumped everything else in at once. It's not brain surgery, no extra bowls, just dump it in and mix it up, then taste and adjust if necessary. My daughter LOVES these and she's picky (17yo that doesn't like sweets usually). If they're sticking to your griddle, you're not greasing it enough. Either use a spray, like Pam, or wipe with paper towel dabbed in oil.
Review:
Rating:
5

region:

country:
None
text:
I've made this recipe a couple of times now. I generally make them to be frozen for my child to toast in the morning before school. 
My work was having an annual holiday brunch. I wanted to so something that harkens back to when we were kids.. So I made these to toast at work. 
I did make some changes. I added:
 1 Tbs brown sugar.
 2 Tbs soften butter 
1 tsp vanilla (doubled from the original)

I also cooked them for 3 min. the night before so they'd be a light - med golden brown. That way they'd darken more in the toaster

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Needed a quick waffle recipe, this is definitely not it. I substituted melted butter for the oil and reduce it by half, nobody needs 1/2 a cup of any oil in any waffle recipe this size. Flavor ok and waffles look perfect, but will not make again,  extremely dense and difficult to cut with a fork. Tried different cooking times in the waffle iron, no difference in the texture. Adding another 1/4 cup of butter or oil to match the original recipe would only have made them worse.  Especially if you have guests, skip over this recipe and find something lighter, fluffier and more classic.  If you like experiments that you can feed to the raccoons later, make this one.

text:
These waffles really are the very best , even better than the ones that call for yeast ( that are also delicious ) . I put my waffle iron on the darkest setting to give them a bit of a crunch and the inside remains fluffy & perfect . I made them exactly as stated & today I added apples and walnuts - they are so good they do not need butter or syrup .  Oh FYI - I also did not use all the batter last week & stored it in fridge as advised , came out just as fresh as the first day !

text:
Really good basic recipe. Followed the recipe exactly the first time. If you’re short on time and just want a good quick recipe, follow this and it will turn out fine. Second time, as per other reviewers, I upped the sugar (1/4 C) and vanilla (2 tsp.) and added 1tsp. cinnamon. For the oil, I used 1/4 C.  vegetable oil and 1/4 C. melted butter so overall amount was the same. I also beat the egg whites first and folded them in at the end. Waffles went from good to great.  Giving 5 stars because the proportions are spot on, the waffles are perfect and the recipe is very adjustable.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I think the basic recipie is good (4 stars). With modifications i will call it a 4.5. We're biased though: buttermilk waffles are the only ones that can score a 5. These are a great alternative when we run out.

Mods:
1 whole wheat flour to 3 a/p flour
1/2 Tbsp (=1.5 tsp) artificial vanilla extract
brown sugar instead of white sugar
decreased butter from 1c (for double batch) to 3/4 c
3/4 tsp salt (for double batch) from 1/2 tsp

userID:
13109470
Display Name:
Nedley Meyers
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
0
favoritesCount:
1
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5416438.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent with these changes: Preheat waffle iron. Beat eggs in large bowl with hand beater until fluffy. Mix eggs, 1 tsp vanilla, 1 3/4 cups mock buttermilk (google recipe for "mock buttermilk") with 1/4 cup melted butter and 1/4 cup peanut oil. In separate bowl, mix flour,  2 Tbsp sugar,  baking powder, salt and 1/2  tsp cinnamon. Mix well. Mix wet ingredients with dry ingredients and whisk until just combined (a few small lumps of flour is fine). ENJOY!
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:

text:
Great recipe. Everyone loved it! Made it with this syrup sauce. Yumm! For Cinnamon Syrup	•	1 cup Granulated Sugar	•	½ cup Milk	•	1 Stick Butter	•	½ tsp Cinnamon	•	½ tsp Baking Soda	•	1 tsp Pure Vanilla ExtractSyrup Instructions	1	In a medium sauce pan heat sugar, milk, butter and cinnamon together over medium high heat.	2	Bring to a boil and boil for 1 minute.	3	Stir in baking soda and vanilla.	4	Mixture will foam so stir for 1 minute.	5	Serve over the waffles.

country:
None
text:
I use this recipe for pancakes for past few years. 
For pancakes, I just add little bit more flour to have thicker batter.
Other option is to make it with less flour and put it in a bottle and in fridge. Then you have it for the whole week, whenever pancakes are needed. Batter will be little darker after few days in the fridge, but it is not spoiled and it is safe to make pancakes or waffles.

Wonderful recipe. Also, as it goes, followed the recommendations from others. Did most of the recipe using a stick blender actually, starting with the egg whites, then mixing in the yolks on low, doubling the white sugar, and adding in brown sugar, and some cinnamon. I also substituted the vegetable oil (because ours has quite a distinct, and not very nice flavour) with olivio margerine. They turned out fantastic.

text:
Received a waffle iron for Christmas, so pick this recipe to give it a try.  I made two changes:  (1) used olive oil instead of vegetable oil (we don't use veggie oil), and (2) used 2 tablespoons of sugar instead of one (I'm a sugar junkie).  The waffles turned out *perfect*...  nice and crisp and full of flavor!  Next time I might try some blueberries or other fruit, or maybe some spices (cinnamon, nutmeg), but this was a great start.  Thanks for sharing!    UPDATE:  I added about 1/2 cup of blueberries this time and it was *really* yummy!

I  like to make recipes exactly as written once, before I decide to modify. I thought the batter was very thick and made a very dense waffle which was a little heavy for my taste. We thinned it with some more milk and it was perfect. I did take the idea in the comments to blend the egg whites to soft peaks separately then fold it into the batter. The thinned out batter produced a light fluffy waffle with an "eggy" taste, which we loved.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3502315.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Light and fluffy waffles -like angel's wings IF you follow these CHANGES: 
* use XL eggs
* use warm whole milk
*seperate the eggs, beat the egg whites until stiff, and set aside. 
* Sift the dry ingredients, combine with the sugar,  egg yolk, milk, & oil until just slightly lumpy 
(overstirring causes tough waffles) and then fold all into the beaten egg whites. 

Makes approx.  (7), 8" x 4.5" double square waffles,  3 1/8oz. each.

-To get the best crispy waffles, make sure your waffle iron comes up to proper temperature again after each batch before starting the next one. Enjoy.

text:
My granddaughter is on Thanksgiving break this week and as soon as Mama dropped her off, she asked Nana for waffles for breakfast. I lost my old recipe and have been looking for another one, and I think I may have found my new recipe! I made these with a few changes.  We like our waffles sweet, and I use Splenda instead of sugar, so I increased it to 1/3 cup and the vanilla to 1 teaspoon. I used melted butter instead of oil - makes all the difference in the world! I used self-rising flour instead of all-purpose, salt, and baking powder (4 teaspoons sounds like waaaaay too much to me!) I mixed these in my blender, starting with whipping up the eggs, then adding the other wet ingredients, then the dry. My granddaughter loved them - I heard a lot of MMMMmmmm's while she was enjoying her waffle!

Mademoiselle Simon

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I didn't have milk, so I used non-fat Chobani Greek yogurt that I thinned out with water in its place. As prepared, this recipe didn't have enough sweetness for my taste. After tasting the first batch I added a layer of turbinado sugar over the batter prior to closing the waffle iron. This addition made the waffles delicious!  They are light and airy, perfectly crispy, yet creamy on the inside. They also freeze well and toast up beautifully from their frozen state, perhaps even better than the day they were made (I think because it adds more caramelization to the  turbinado sugar). Make these waffles, you won't regret it!  Next time I'm going to try coconut oil instead of vegetable oil.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was fine on it's own and if you wish to follow as is, you'll yield good waffles.
My daughter makes a double recipe of waffles regularly for our family of six to enjoy throughout the week. We use his recipe as a jumping point and mostly double everything. But we use half whole wheat, just half a cup oil, four beaten egg whites (no yolks), two tsp. cinnamon and 1/4 cup white sugar.  It yields a hearty yet light waffle with less fat. We freeze and reheat in the toaster, often making cream cheese and jelly waffle sandwiches for school lunches during the week.
My review (stars) is for the original recipe because I dislike when people rate their own version. That's not a rating of the recipe at all. So, as is, 4 stars and a perfectly fine, though slightly bland waffle. I give it 5 stars with our alterations, keeping in mind we like whole wheat baked goods and crisp waffles.
