text:
It's okay. It's a decent waffle recipe, but don't expect anything spectacular out of it. It's not as terrible as the 1-star reviews, but it's also not as great as the 5-star reviews. I followed the recipe the first time, but didn't like the oily taste, and from then on substituted applesauce for the cooking oil. I don't think it makes much of a difference. The mix is also very liquidy, and that makes it difficult to judge how fast you're pouring it onto your waffle iron. It's a decent recipe if you're looking for a no-frills waffle recipe, but don't expect anything too great.

region:

country:
None
text:
I made this recipe exactly as written and they were the best waffles I've ever made.  Light and fluffy!  I may cut down on the oil next time since my lips taste buttery.

*Revised, 1/24: I have made these several times since my first review and I've made the following revisions to make it dairy free and slightly healthier...they are waffles, so already a splurge. Substitutions:
scant 1/4 c sunflower oil instead of 1/2c oil
1 tsp vanilla instead of 1/2t 
1 tsp REAL maple syrup & omit cane sugar
Used the same amount of Almond Milk vs dairy milk

We could not taste the difference! Beating the eggs and the baking powder really make these v light and fluffy.  If I put them in a batter dispenser to use throughout the week, I have to add it gradually as the batter rises as it sits.  It also separates a lot during the week so we've found we prefer to make them all at once and reheat.

text:
These waffles turned our way too dense, like lead though maybe because I used 2 packed cups of flour there was too much flour. So after I was displeased with the first four waffles, I added 1/2 cup water and 1/2 cup more oil and another tablespoon of sugar  to the second batch which turned out  moister, lighter and fluffier. Recipe made 10 waffles with a four-waffle waffle iron.  Next time I will add 3/4 cup water and more oil to try and get crispier, less doughy waffles.  Or I will just buy Aunt Jemima Waffle Mix which is best one on the market--better than these waffles!

text:
Never have I encountered a horrific, unhonorable, and dissatisfying piece of false advertisement as this. I followed your recipe. I even watched your video. I gazed in amazement as those luxurious l, beautiful mouth watering golden brown waffles appeared out of your waffle maker. And yet, little to my knowledge you were being deceitful. You must've used another recipe. That is my only explanation for what happened next. I added my ingredients one by one, as your trusting and elegant voice had led me to believe was the correct way to do so. I poured the batter in "just enough to fill [the waffle maker] as you led me to believe. And once the green light went off, I gained a new sense of hope. See now for some time I have lost my hope, drowning in the work brought on by my studies. Yet you had inspired me. I stumbled upon your waffle recipe while looking up research for a critical essay, and it inspired me. But that inspiration and hope would soon die, as I lifted to waffle maker open only to gaze upon the most hideous sight I've ever seen. A burnt waffle on the outside, and yet somehow extremely raw on the inner side. My heart dropped. See I have never found love, but this was the closest I've ever come to it. And it was taken away from me in seconds. There wasn't even a sense of waffle in the taste. Just the sense of realization that there is nothing to look forward to in this life. What is there in life if you can't even make a waffle. What is there, I dare you answer that qu

I haven't actually made these yet, but the recipe looks great!  I am writing because when I sent it to print,  the quantities for  the ingredients came out in grams and milligrams and not the actual measuring amounts.  I thought someone should be aware of this and get it corrected.  I crossed out the printed amounts and wrote in the actual measurements.  Thanks!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3942041.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great and easy waffle recipe! I used to make Belgian waffles all the time for my kids, but now they're all teenagers and with how quick they gobble everything down without even tasting it. I'll save the Belgian and Liege waffles for special occasions...The taste is great. The outside is crispy, and the inside is tender... I have tried other basic waffle recipes, but the best thing about this one is the consistency of the batter. It is a bit thinner, and makes pouring it onto the iron a breeze. Some of the other batters that are even just a bit thicker are a pain to spread out and sometimes require the use a rubber spatula to move it around a bit, and by that time the top of the iron has cooled off.  Sometimes it's those little things that count the most when making breakfast for 6.

userID:
21465133
Display Name:
Dena Schwartz
isPro:
False
followersCount:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have to admit, my family and I are Krusteaz fans. I promised my son and his friends waffles this morning (sleepover) and when I went to reach for the Krusteaz, it was gone. My husband made a batch the day before and there was only enough leftover batter to make two waffles. I quickly Googled a recipe and this one was the first to pop up. With such a high rating I figured it was a safe bet. 

The only alteration I made to the recipe was in using skim milk (it's all I have in the house); other than that, I followed it to the letter. I like a crispy waffle, inside and out, and the Krusteaz are always a little soft inside. These waffles, however, were perfectly crispy inside and out. On the flavor side, however, I found them to be pretty bland. I added extra vanilla and sugar, and also added cinnamon before making a second round of waffles and the taste was better, but I still didn't LOVE them. The predominant flavor was that of flour.

I used up the rest of the Krusteaz batter to do a taste test. My son, his friends and I were all in agreement, the Krusteaz was better due to flavor.  The boys also liked that the Krusteaz was crispy on the outside and soft and fluffy on the inside. And you know what? After comparing a waffle that is through and through crispy to one that is only crispy on the outside, I have changed my mind.  I preferred the crispness of the Krusteaz too. The boys did make one observation in favor of the homemade waffles. They all agreed that the homemade waffl
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2017-02-12T15:16:24.37

text:
Believe it or not, in all of my 40 years I have never made waffles. Probably because I never owned a waffle maker. I'm not sure why, just didn't LOL. So I got one as a gift and my kids were having a snow day, and I realized we were out of their favorite breakfast in the freezer, and going to the store was a no go. I googled how to make waffles and found this recipe. I love it because I always have all of the things in the ingredients list. Most recipes I came across call for buttermilk, which I never just keep on hand because I don't use it that much. This is a simple, and wonderful recipe. Very yummy waffles. They come out perfect and my kids just loved them.

country:
None
text:
You can't beat two eggs and then add two cups of flour directly afterwards. You'll end up with a congealed mess that won't mix properly into batter. Do wet and dry separately, mix well in each, then combine.

Also, another reviewer was right, these are bland. What they need is more salt, not more sugar.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4380445.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe! It's wonderful just as it is. It's a very simple recipe to whip up. The only thing I did different, is add some chocolate chips to them, because my son really wanted them in his waffles. He loved them! I gave them to my 2 year old without adding syrup to it & she loved them! No syrup is needed when you include chocolate chips. However, I do agree with what many others are saying about it in terms of flavor. It is quite bland if you are not planning on using syrup & if you haven't included chocolate chips to the recipe. I do find it needs that extra bit of sweetness, but I think most people like eating waffles with syrup anyhow. If you prefer to not use syrup, then you may want to take some of the suggestions other users have given. There are many different options to spice up the flavor.  I'm planning on adding a bit of cinnamon & nutmeg next time I make them. I will also increase the amount of sugar & vanilla I put in.  

Overall, this is a fantastic recipe worthy of a 5 start rating! Even with the small modifications that you make to it, I still give credit to the allrecipes member who submitted this recipe. I plan on using this recipe over & over again! 

Thank you for sharing this great recipe! ??

text:
3 stars for the taste ! these were so bland. I made them the 1st time following the  exact recipe and we had to smother the waffles with  all kind of sweet toppings to give them some taste.
The 2nd time, I tripled the salt and the sugar and doubled the vanilla. NOW, they deserve 5 stars !
When making waffles, I always turn the oven on, to 250 and put in a cookie sheet topped with a cooling rack. And as I am making the waffles, I put them on that cooling rack in the oven. That keeps all the waffles crispy and warm til serving time.

text:
Best waffles ever! Thanks for sharing it!
I replaced the oil for coconut oil. Used whole wheat white flour.  2 Tbsp brown sugar, a pinch of nutmeg & Ginger. Beat the egg whites separately as other reviewers suggested. Folded wet ingredients into dry. Poured about 1/3 cup batter per waffle. Cooked each batch for 3 minutes. Delicious!!!!

I made it again on 2/11/18 with white flour, adding a cup of sour cream, 1/4 tsp nutmeg, 1/4 tsp baking soda, and orange liqueur instead of vanilla. My son said my best waffles ever!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I noticed that most of the people who didn't give it 5 stars changed something in the recipe. If you make it exactly as written, the waffles turn out perfectly. The secret I think is to beat all of the wet ingredients together well before adding the dry ingredients. Beat the dry ingredients only until blended. Don't over-beat. The only things I did different were that I used 1% milk and 3 small eggs since I didn't have large eggs. They don't need extra sugar or vanilla to taste as waffles are supposed to taste. It made 8 waffles at 273 calories each.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great basic recipe to work off of. I prefer to use Brown sugar and coconut oil for a nice flavor. Sometimes I add a bit of cinnamon too! I have a suspicion that those who really hated the recipe did not make it right. Look carefully at teaspoon vs tablespoon for your baking power measurement. I also saw some people say all they could taste was baking SODA! Baking soda is not the same thing as baking powder and would taste God awful in this recipe, so just make sure you are using the correct amount of baking POWDER and these should come out just fine!

text:
We love this recipe!!! I always have a batch in the fridge ready to go. We are a GF family so we substitute the flour with Bobs Red Mill 1 to1 flour. You could never tell they are gluten free. We also substitute the sugar with 3TBS coconut sugar and the vegetable oil for coconut oil. My next experiment will be to replace the flour with a grain free version. We also use a restaurant style waffle maker. The kind you have to flip over and seen at most hotels. It makes the outside slightly crispy and the inside so soft and almost gooey ! Oh I love these waffles! I highly recommend this recipe it's Excellent.

userID:
3364967
Display Name:
pwwong2
isPro:

9
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I tried this waffle recipe and the classic waffle recipe. Both are well reviewed by users. No modifications were made to either and I use a cheap waffle maker for both. Both were successful but the consistency of the batter is significantly different. This recipe uses more milk and oil (415 vs 355ml & 120 vs 75 g butter/veg oil) hence the batter is MUCH thinner.  This waffle basically sizzled in my maker producing more oil and steam before getting a crispy end product. It does have an airy texture to it but not what you expect from  restaurant waffles. That said, maybe its my not so professional waffle maker that is at fault. It was flat, crispy and a light slightly cake like texture although it was way too oily. I am not the health nut type and love my butter but will definitely reduce it to 70 gram for my next batch. I guess more people tried this recipe and that is why it has more ratings but most of the reviews involved modifications especially to the amounts of oil. I would do the same if you decide to try this recipe. A thinner batter is already hard to work with and cleaning up the oil around the maker is another chore. It is however a good recipe for a home taste waffle.

The other recipe produced a better waffle that resembles the type in a restaurant. It had enough height and crispiness, possibly because batter is also thicker and that allowed the iron on both sides to work its magic. It is also easier to manage.  

Thankfully both produced decent waffles but if I h

Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-07-06T22:12:32.44
helpfulCount:
0

text:
I love this recipe, I use it every time I make waffles! I add a pinch of salt and use vanilla bean instead of vanilla extract. I also sometimes slightly undercook them by about thirty seconds to a minute so that I can freeze them and heat them back up in the toaster and they won't come out too crunchy. They're perfect for when you're late for work and have no time to make anything else ^u^

text:
I love this recipe!  I did make a few changes.  I used Fairlife low fat milk to up the protein and reduce the fat, coconut oil melted for the oil, Splenda instead of sugar, sugar free vanilla syrup, increased the vanilla extract and added vanilla protein powder to increase protein.  They where very filling and husband and grand-babies LOVED them!

I made plain waffles, blueberry waffles, and chocolate chip waffles, all with this same recipe. It is my go-to recipe for waffles now.

text:
I like to make a recipe the way it states before making any changes so I can review it accordingly.  The only thing I changed was I blended all of the ingredients in the blender.  I put the eggs in first, blended,  then added the rest of the ingredients and they are indeed fluffy with a crispy outside.  The only thing they lack is taste.  They are so bland!  I am adding cinnamon to the rest of the batter and maybe even some ginger and nutmeg but yeah...add some flavor unless you like bland food ;)  But overall, great base recipe!

I just added nutmeg, cinnamon and ginger and it's slightly better.  I think maybe adding applesauce in lieu of some oil might give it some flavor and doubling the vanilla?  I'm sure some reviewers said the same thing, just don't want to read them all ;)

text:
My son has milk and egg allergies so I  had to substitute the soymilk for the milk and powdered egg replacer for the egg.  Given that, my results might be different than the recipe as written.  With my substitutions these were okay but a bit bland.  I added dried cranberries to one and that was much better.  My son ate them with maple syrup but seemed to agree that without adding something sweet, they are too bland to really want to eat.

text:
This is a very yummy waffle recipe but, the ingredients need to be rewritten for it to not be so lumpy. Next time I will  put eggs in one bowl and beat them then in a separate bowl add all dry ingredients, add milk, oil and vanilla to beaten eggs, then slowly add dry ingredients in. I believe this will make a not so lumpy end product!

text:
Took the healthier route as recommended by others with great results:
Vanilla Noosa Yogurt in place of oil.
Whole wheat flour (a bit more)
Skim milk (a bit less)
2 tsp fresh lemon juice.
2 tsp vanilla.
1/4 tsp cinnamon.
Whipped Egg whites separate folded in at the end.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious and easy!  I used non fat milk and doubled the recipe because I had a large group for breakfast.  They were perfect.  At first I thought they could have used a little more sugar, but then I realized I had maple syrup and boysenberry syrup, so they did not need any extra sugar in the batter.  My granddaughter said they were the best waffles she ever had. Everyone loved them, and they were gone in a flash.  Will use this recipe again for sure, and will try the plain yogurt in place of the oil as another reviewer mentioned.
Update...two weeks later I made them again...only used one quarter oil, which was sufficient.  Also, doubled the vanilla.  Added an extra half tsp of sugar.  In my estimation, the sugar is probably un necessary, because you can't taste it anyway, and if you are going to use syrup you wil have plenty of sweetness.  
The waffles were great, this is a good basic recipe..
Have also served these with sliced banana and whipped cream!  6/24/18 update: made these again, for company, substituted plain nonfat yoghurt for the oil, put in about 1 tsp of oil " just in case" it needs something to not stick.  They were so light, and so delicious.  Didn't get a chance to take a picture, they were gobbled up!  This is the ONLY waffle recipe I consistently use.

text:
This is a great base recipe! I definitely recommend reading reviews before making as there are some excellent recommendations for adjustments. I made these today and I increased the white sugar to 2 1/2 TBSP, added 1/2 TBSP of ground cinnamon to the flour mixture, and I put the flour, baking powder, and cinnamon into a sifter and then sifted into the wet portion of the mix. I also tossed in sliced almonds once I poured the batter onto the griddle for some extra healthfulness! Yum!

Loved the recipe, the waffles were  tasty and light and not too sweet. Just right! One change I made the second time around was, I separated the egg white from the yolk and beat the whites until they were all foam, then I gently stirred them in at the very end. It made the waffles extra fluffy.

userID:
4146165
Display Name:
gourmetcook0921
isPro:

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My mistake turned out to be a hit! Instead of using vegetable oil, I cut the amount of vegetable oil in half and used coconut oil for the other half. My mistake was adding the warm liquid coconut oil to the cold milk and let it sit while I used a hand mixer to whip the egg whites. The coconut oil solidified. 

Instead of pitching the milk, egg yokes, vegetable oil, coconut oil and vanilla, I broke up the solidified oil and proceeded to mix the wet ingredients with the dry ingredients, then folded in the egg whites. 

It ended up fantastic! The solidified coconut oil acted like butter cut into pastry would. It turned the waffles crispy on the outside and soft and springy on the inside. Yummers.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-03-12T09:33:21.127

text:
I make this recipe on Sunday mornings and freeze leftovers to be reheated during the busy weekdays. I do make some healthy substitutions. I use Oat Flour (which is also gluten free) instead of white flour, coconut oil instead of the vegetable oil, 1 TSP raw honey instead of the sugar and 1/4 tsp of cinnamon and I increase vanilla to 1 TSP.  The honey sweetens it very well and all my kids and husband gobble it up! I do also like to separate the egg whites (as was recommended by a previous poster), then use a hand mixer to beat egg whites until fluffy and fold in as the last step!

text:
Best part of making these waffles was watching my 7-year old take off his pajama top, so he can enjoy the yummy waffles without getting syrup on his top. In all seriousness, this is a great recipe.  modified it based on what I had (or did not have) in my pantry this morning. I was out of vanilla extract but had Starbucks vanilla syrup; I used 2 pumps to replace both the sugar and vanilla extract. I had a smidge more milk left so I ended up using 2 cups of it instead of 1 and 3/4. I added a handful of chopped walnuts I served them to my family for breakfast, topped with butter and maple syrup. They loved it! Thank you for sharing the recipe, photo, and video!

region:

country:
None
text:
I was feeding 8, so I doubled it. I separated the egg whites and beat them with 3/4 tsp cream of tartar and the sugar, 'til they were somewhere between soft and stiff peaked.  Folded it in to the rest of the mix 1/3 first, and then the rest,  and cooked the first waffle.  The texture was just right, but it had no taste,  I doubled the vanilla, added a bit (maybe 1/4 tsp)  of almond extract, a couple Tbsp. of brown sugar and crushed and added a handful of pecans.  Next waffle was perfect.  I forget the actual yield,  but we only had two left over with eight people at the table.

userID:
17270348
Display Name:
Whitney Centeno
isPro:
False
followersCount:
4
followingCount:
0

8
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4614387.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the second recipe I've tried and the last one I'll ever try!  I doubled the vanilla and sugar and added 1/2 tsp of cinnamon. I'm new at waffle making so it took some trial and error. So this may help a few of you: I set my Oster 3883 to medium high (in the middle of the middle dot and first "max" dot) and I cooked them for 4 1/2- minutes. I noticed it took a lot of time for my very first waffle to crisp. Even though the "ready" light was on it still wasn't hot enough I'm assuming.  Anyway, I also do not have a mixer or whisk. I used a fork for mixing and it still turned out good. I'm sure using a hand mixer will make them even better! I added the beat egg yokes to the mixing bowl first. All the dry ingredients, then mixed (without touching the yokes at the bottom.) Then I mixed the liquid ingredients in a different bowl, added them to the mixing bowl and beat until all lumps were gone. I did my best at fluffing egg whites in a small, separate bowl then folded them in. I used a 2/3 measuring cup to pour my batter in. Butter flavored cooking spray. This recipe made 5 waffles. Hope this helps someone!
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
Made this with a few tweaks and it was wonderful. I heard all sorts of yummy noises being made at the table and the house smells wonderful!

Tweaks: Butter instead of oil. I almost always substitute
butter for oil in recipes that use flour.  I doubled the vanilla, used two tablespoons of brown sugar (no white). Brown sugar adds a caramel flavor that I love!  I put in a few healthy shakes of cinnamon and a few shakes of allspice. I separated the eggs and beat the whites, which I folded in at the end. 

They were fluffy, crisp, and had a really wonderful flavor. Served with organic maple syrup. I'm going to use the leftover batter to make waffle sundaes for dessert.

OMG...so perfect!  I studied all the reviews for a bunch of waffle recipes, and this seemed to be the best one.  I'm glad I found this recipe, it is the first and last one I will ever need. photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1927769.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just received a waffle iron from my daughter, and this is the third and best waffle recipe yet! I tweaked it by using melted coconut oil (because of all the health benefits), 1 tablespoon baking powder, and 1 tablespoon vanilla. The coconut oil makes them nice and crispy on the outside, so they don't go soggy after I add syrup.  Thanks for sharing this fantastic waffle recipe!!! UPDATE: I made this recipe today, leaving out the oil and not replacing it with anything. I used 1/3 cup whole wheat flour, the rest white.  I added 1/2 teaspoon of baking soda for lift. The waffles were light and tasty, but they were difficult to lift out of the iron. Usually, I just use a fork with long tines, but with this batter I had to use a long pancake turner to support the waffle during lifting it out. Still, given the benefits of fat free with a bit of added fiber, the extra work was worth it. I will be making this recipe without the oil again.
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
I love these waffles!!!! Before trying these I was hooked on the Belgian waffle recipe but it just took too long! The changes I made was to add more vanilla ( but I always do that), chocolate chips for the kiddos, brown sugar, cinnamon, beat egg whites separately and change the oil to applesauce (based on other reviews).  Great change.  I didn't taste the difference at all.  Also, instead of spraying the waffle iron, I brush it with coconut oil ( I heard that it preserves the waffle iron longer).   The waffles were crispy on the outside and soft on the inside.  My whole family loved them!

Display Name:
Amy Wall-Steffen

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2791173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this waffle recipe.  I have made it several dozen times.
The only modifications I do is sometimes add one extra egg and a HUGE yam or 2 large mashed / pureed yams.  You literally can never have too much yam in these.
I roast my yams (sometimes the night before) then use a teaspoon of butter or a tad of water and my electric beaters to puree them.  I make the recipe as usual and mix it then I add my puree'd yams and mix with electric beaters again till smooth.  My kids far prefer them made with yams as they are sweet and I prefer them as its just a little more nutrition for them.  I make these every weekend and freeze them in a single layer then store them in a ziplock and put them in my sons lunch a few days a week.  If using them at breakfast I thaw for 30 seconds in the microwave then lightly toast them.  Yummm.

As suggested by others, I separated the eggs and beat the whites till peaks formed, then I added the whites last. I also added cinnamon & brown sugar and substituted applesauce for the oil. I doubled the recipe: using 1 cup of Sarah's applesauce from all recipes, finely pureed: 2 t brown sugar and 1 t cinnamon. It was a hit.  I have a belgian waffle maker that makes 4 waffles at a time. Doubled, this recipe made 18. Perfect for my family of 6. Thanks! No more boxed waffle mixes for us!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious and adjustable! As others said, you can easily omit the oil for apple sauce, but I find that even unsweetened apple sauce tends to make the waffle stick more. If you go the wheat flour route, expect it to be a thicker batch (the apple sauce helps cut thin it out though).  The best part of the recipe is you can easily add fruit or chocolate chips or both! My personal favourite is bananas and blueberries, and the apple sauce compliments both nicely. My only warning about this recipe is the amounts; at half the recipe my waffle iron can easily make 2 giant waffles. For those who are light eaters or have children, I strongly recommend cutting the recipe in half, if not you can easily have these again the day after!

text:
The recipe was good.  After I read other reviews and adjusted, the recipe went from good to perfect. 
I used egg whites and beat them in a separate bowl. I used Greek plain no fat yogurt in place of the oil. Put in 2 tsp of vanilla and 1 1/2 tsp cinnamon - because we both love cinnamon. I beat all ingredients except the whites. Then I folded in the beaten whites. Talk about light and fluffy, it remained so to the last waffle baking. 
Thank you for posting this because I always wanted to make waffles from scratch but felt I was not knowledgeable enough to try making it on my own. With this recipe I felt I could take my first step and go for it.

country:

text:
First making:  these were fine, but a little bland.  Still looking around for the best waffle!

I just made for a second time today.  I followed the instructions of another reviewer, and these turned out delicious!  Ingredient changes:  2T of white sugar, 2T of brown sugar, 1-1/2t vanilla.  Building changes:  Separate the eggs, and whip the egg whites until light and fluffy.  Add yolks, milk, oil, and vanilla, mixing in between addition of each.  Mix dry goods in a separate bowl, and then combine the dry mixture to the liquid mixture.

None
text:
My family usually skips breakfast because of extended "beauty sleep", but I decided to make some breakfast this morning. I made these waffles with whole wheat flour, half the oil the recipe called for, double the vanilla and sugar, folded in egg whites with stiff peaks, and used buttermilk instead of regular milk, but the waffles were bit of a disappointment. They sort of turned out to be grainy and sort of sandy, dry and flavorless (until I added some honey and butter).I wanted to take the healthier choice, so I chose to used whole wheat flour, but I think it might of tasted better with just all purpose white flour. I don't get the people who commented that the whole wheat alternative was better. I think I admit that this is a great recipe, but it did not work out for me. Even though they tasted funny, most of it was gone by the end of breakfast.

text:
I made the recipe with whole wheat flour.  I had to use two hands to get my waffle iron open.  The waffles didn't stick, though, so I don't know if oil was the problem, but I'd like to try the recipe with more oil next time.  I guess they were kind of bland, but I'm used to having maple syrup on my waffles, and I ate these ones plain.  The recipe was easy, though, and, aside from the grittiness and dark color from the whole wheat flour, they had the texture and fluffiness I expect from waffles.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was the recipe that moved me to sign up and leave my first review. Great base recipe, but like others I made some small modifications to add flavor, as well as some build changes in putting it together. When prepping the batter, I first mixed all dry ingredients in a separate bowl.Then I separated the egg whites and blended well about medium speed with a electric mixer - basically until really frothy - 2 min or so. I then added all wet ingredients in, to include the egg yolks, and mixed on low until combined. I then added in the dry ingredients. Once all was blended together, you could really tell how light the batter was. It was different than just a regular wet batter. For the flavoring change, I just doubled the vanilla extract and white sugar. I made a couple plain, and they turned out excellent. I had some mini chocolate chips, so I mixed some of those in on the next two and they were awesome. Waffle was crisp on the outside and perfect on the inside. In my waffling experiences, you either get soggy and wet, or crispy and dry. This recipe finds a perfect happy medium.

I found this recipe last night and started it this morning as my 3 year old decided she wanted to help, didn't want to help, wanted to play, wanted to pretend to be a baby in Daddy's arms.....while on the phone with my Mom (every Sunday since I left home for college) listening to her tell me things about her week she just got finished telling me.....and somehow I managed not to $#%! it up! text:
I've made these several times, and I've always liked them, but my husband says they're too egg-y. After telling me that I tried to use one egg instead of two and he said they're still too egg-y.

Also, for those who say it's too much oil, try substituting it with butter. When making waffles, I have always used butter instead of oil because I like the butter flavor but it's impossible to spread it on waffles. :)

text:
I used white whole wheat flour, and followed other reviewers suggestions to whip the egg whites first, add additional vanilla and some cinnamon to the batter.  I also used 1/2 melted coconut oil and 1/2 vegetable oil.  My batter was a bit thick so I also added about 1/4 cup of cinnamon applesauce to thin it out a bit.  The waffles cooked great and were very tasty!  I am going to try to freeze them now to see how that works as well.

text:
Just made these and they turned out perfect! My hubby (who is a picky eater and hates trying new things) looked bummed when I said we were out of mix and I couldn't find my recipie so I was trying a new one ... I used my grandmother's trick of beating the eggs and milk until frothy, then added everything else plus a Tbl of cinnamon. Needless to say, two waffles and two thumbs up later, my hubby rates this 5 stars lol. I put the other half into a ziploc bag and put in the freezer as another suggested so I can just move it to the fridge the night before I want to use it to thaw. I'll be making this recipe again for sure! Thanks!

text:
These were the first waffles I have ever made from scratch and I was very pleased with how they came out. My husband was also! I followed some of the helpful reviews and doubled the sugar and vanilla extract. I also added cinnamon (1/4 tsp). I can't imagine what they would have been like without doing that because although they were very good, they weren't very sweet; they were ALMOST bland. I also beat the egg whites separately, as recommended by some. They were fluffy on the inside and crispy on the outside. Yum! (Not sure if that was due to the perfect timing of my waffle maker, though.) I would make these again.

I made this recipe for my niece one morning for breakfast, and she loved it!  I didn't have any eggs, so I used flax seed egg replacer (1 T ground flax seed + 3 T water for each egg being replaced) and coconut milk instead of dairy.  I also added the 1/2 t cinnamon and 1 t brown sugar as suggested by others.  She's a teenager, and while she's not super picky, I was a little unsure if she'd like them or not.  She scarfed several waffles down, and I plan to make more next time she spends the night!

text:
I really enjoyed these waffles. I think those that had issues with the waffles being soggy didn't have their waffle iron on a hot enough setting. If your waffle iron is set on low, this recipe yields waffles that are soft like pancakes. Set the waffle iron a little hotter and you'll get that lovely crisp outside, soft inside that you're aiming for. 

I made the recipe as written originally. Had I not used vanilla almond milk and extra vanilla, I think they would have been a bit too bland. After the first batch, I mixed in extra sugar and some cinnamon and they were divine. 

I agree with those posters who say that 4 tbsp of baking powder is unnecessary. I really believe you could get by just fine with two. If you don't add extra sugar and seasoning, you can taste a hint of the baking powder--and you don't want that. I like this recipe and will be keeping it. This works great with almond milk!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2014-08-25T19:07:18.24

country:
None
text:
This is a good recipe, giving nice waffles with a good texture. They're not as flavorful as waffles made with buttermilk / sour milk. I've made it several times. The recipe as written is a bit over-complicated, with the beating of the eggs, etc.  As an experiment, I didn't beat the eggs using a mixer.  I broke up the eggs using a fork, then added the milk and oil, then combined the liquid mixture to the dry mixture with a wire wisk.  No difference in the texture that I could detect.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Unless you add lots of batter to the waffle maker, waffles do not turn out fluffy; they're flat simply because the recipe doesn't have a lot of baking powder (unlike similar recipes).  Once you get used to this recipe, it's okay, but there's still a slight problem with the waffles sticking to the waffle maker. Also, the problem of lumps forming in batter is probably caused by adding flour and baking powder after liquids. Taste of the thicker waffles was fine, so I'm glad I gave this recipe a second chance :-)

Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2014-06-15T09:21:49.753

country:
None
text:
Separating the eggs is a must.  I also added cinnamon as suggested by others. Yummy.  I didn't have milk, but I had buttermilk. I prefer butter to veg oil so I substituted.  I had to cook them a bit longer as they were a little soggy.  Next time adding another egg will probably help as the batter was a bit thick, which is probably why it took longer to cook them to perfection.  But the flavour was well worth it.  I also add 4 tablespoons of sugar since my little one doesn't like maple syrup, but likes them sweet.  These are NOT diet friendly.  A once in a while treat for sure.  Wear your maternity pants because you will want to indulge.

text:
Okay, so I already loved this recipe.  The only thing I changed was to add 1/4 cup of sugar because I like my waffles sweet.  Add however much or little as you want, your recipe.  HOWEVER, I have been experimenting with gluten free recipes using pamela's artisan all purpose flour and I have been seriously disappointed in my substitutions the few times I have tried.  That being said, I LOVED these waffles gluten free. I might even like them better gluten free then with all purpose flour.  Holy Cow they are good.  I don't know how to describe it but the texture is wicked delicious and the flavor was sure tasty.  For any of you gluten free-ers, give it ago.  I did a one for one substitution.  Most Excellent!

text:
This recipe is awesome. Very light and fluffy. I will never use a boxed mix again! I have a non-stick waffle iron so I cut back on the oil. I used only 1/4 cup. They did not stick at all. They did however ooze out of the iron, I guess because of the liquid or the baking powder. I also made a batch with half of the salt and I will freeze them for my Mom who is on a sodium restricted diet. A quarter of a teaspoon of salt divided between 9 large waffles can't be too high in sodium. Everyone liked them even my fussy husband kept saying how much better these tasted. If he only knew how easy it was to make waffles from scratch he would want them all of the time.

text:
I have tried this recipe multiple times and have found it to be a great recipe. I follow the recipe exactly with no alterations and its always fluffy on the inside and crispy on the outside. Great for doubling the recipe and freezing the leftovers to toast on a busy morning. I freeze two dozen at a time for an easy breakfast for my toddler and me and I have never been disappointed, they keep very well. Also, to some of the reviews who complained of soggy waffles, it may just be the waffle iron itself, the oil in this recipe calls for a high cook temperature, maybe switch out the oil for butter or margarine instead? Just a suggestion. Definitely will recommend this recipe.

text:
I've tried this recipe three times now, and it's great! 1st time, the only change was adding cinnamon & doubling the vanilla. The 2nd time, I substituted 1 cup wheat flour & 1 cup flax seed for the white flour (& still added cinnamon & vanilla) - awesome & healthier!! Today, I added 1 tbsp of brown sugar, just used white flour, added the cinnamon & vanilla, and HAD to use 1/2 Olive oil because I ran out of veg oil, and it was still awesome! Also, ran out of syrup, so had to use agave syrup, which was healthier anyway!  :)

I like this recipe. I have tried others, but this was easy and has nice flavors. I did make minor changes. I used half melted butter, half olive oil. I used one cup heavy cream and the rest milk. I boosted the vanilla, and added a handful of fine ground white corn meal. The flavors were wonderful, and the texture was very good. Had left over batter, so I made the rest and put them in the freezer. I will be using this recipe often.

I've made this recipe 3 times now and feel I didn't get it just right until the 3rd try. First time following Tevans211 suggestions to make it healthier (minus the splenda b/c didn't have) - and if you're not a cinnamon lover then I recommend omitting. Tevans211 suggestions for a healthier was exactly that...heathier and tasted as such; which is great just didn't do justice for me. I really wanted to fulfill my taste buds of eating waffles when I was a kid. Round 2 I tried to be healthy by using apple sauce but by round 3 I followed the recipe exactly (I did't follow any reviews alterations) and it was just what I was looking for. I put peanut butter and the syrup and it was perfect! Thanks Tevans211 for suggesting to put leftovers in the freezer - delicious!

Tasty!  Everybody loved this.  I made a few changes including using half whole wheat flour and half white, doubling the vanilla and sugar and substituting melted butter for the oil and a bit of cinnamon.  The full recipe made only 5 waffles and the batter didn't really pour...I had to spread it on the waffle iron with a spatula.  I think I would double the ingredients next time because I think these waffles would freeze and keep well.

text:
I make these waffles for my family, and my kids say I "make the best waffles in the world!". I also tweak the recipe just a little bit. I change the number of servings from 6 to 4, but still use 2 eggs. I stumbled upon this by accident when I followed the directions exactly, but used jumbo eggs instead of regular ones. The extra egg makes the waffles incredibly light and airy. The texture is less like a pancake and more like a cruller. You can't stop eating them.

text:
This was a fantastic and quick, easy waffle recipe!   it made 4 full and 2 smaller Belgian waffles.  I followed the recipe pretty much except added 1 1/2 t Lemon juice to the milk.  Added only 1/4 cup oil.  Added 1/4 cup splenda instead of real sugar.  A good couple shakes of cinnamon. I also beat the eggs to give them some fluffiness. Poured short of 1 cup in the belgian waffle maker. kept warm in oven til ready!   So YUMMY!

Display Name:
browntoole

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4249515.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a good recipe, but after adding things I couldn't give it a 5 star. As suggested, I added 1 teaspoon of vanilla, 2 tablespoons of sugar, 2-3 teaspoons of cinnamon. I used cup of buttermilk and 3/4 cup of regular milk. I made the buttermilk, I also separated the egg yolks from the white and with the egg white I mixed them with the blender until they formed peaks ( You can also add the sugar to the egg white instead of the batter in order to make them fluffier, I haven't tried the recipe that way yet)and I added the egg yolk to the liquid batter and folded in the egg whites with a spatula at the end. I didn't need to spray my waffle iron, when I spray the iron the they don't brown that well. They were crispier too. Next time, I will try a dash of nutmeg as suggested.  I also added a 2 tablespoons oil and and 1 tablespoon of cornstarch to add to the crispy texture. Delicious!

userID:
10810447
Display Name:
USMC

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So glad I found this waffle recipe!!  Just because I needed to use it up, I added 1 cup buttermilk & just 1 cup regular milk instead of the 1 3/4 cup of milk the recipe calls for. Substituted unsweetened applesauce for the oil.  Haven't tried adding more sugar or vanilla as other posts have suggested, maybe next time.   Otherwise, I didn't tweak the recipe & received NO complaints from 4 extremely picky boys :)
Best suggestions I have are to make sure your waffle iron is really hot (so they'll come out crispy) and make sure your waffle iron is greased well, even between batches (I used Bakers Joy brand spray).   I mixed my "wet" ingredients in my Kitchen Aid on stir speed while I prepared all the "dry" ingredients in a separate bowl & then added gradually to the wet mix & blended all for about 1 minute on speed 2. 
Great recipe - will use it every week!

None
text:
Overall, a very good recipe that yields light and crispy waffles, but it needs some extra oomph. I make these waffles and freeze them for my husband who gets up for work at 430 every morning (they freeze beautifully, for the record). We don't use much syrup, so we prefer our waffles on the sweeter side. I doubled the sugar (but used xylitol instead) and added more vanilla. Even so, my husband still did not find them sweet enough. Easy enough to fix. I also used white whole wheat flour and found that I needed to add just a little smidgen of extra milk to get the batter to a good consistency.

text:
So yummy!  I mixed all of the dry ingredients thoroughly in a bowl then put all the liquid ingredients in a blender for about 60 seconds.  I mixed wet and dry ingredients in the bowl just until blended together.  SUBSTITUTIONS: Used melted coconut oil instead of vegetable oil, almond milk, and organic white whole wheat flour for extra nutrition.  Kept measurements the same.  Did not need non-stick cooking spray.  It did not stick at all, but then again that depends on your waffle iron.  Baked them all at once to freeze.

text:
Pretty yummy! We only have 2% milk in our house so to make it a little richer, I reduced the milk to 1 1/2 cups and added 1 heaping tablespoon of sour cream & 1 tablespoon melted butter. Was a little worried I was going too far off the reservation with the sour cream but it was awesome! The finished product was a little moist inside and had a super RICH flavor.  I also followed some of the other posters and doubled the sugar and vanilla extract. Totally yummy and the only batter I'll use for waffles from now on!

text:
This is our family's go-to waffle recipe. Beating the eggs is a important step I making a crisp exterior and a fluffy interior. I found that when doing 100% whole wheat flour the waffles were not as easy to release from the waffle maker. I found that 1/2 whole wheat and 1/2 AP works extremely well though. We like to add bananas, pecans and cinnamon to our batter... Or fresh blueberries.

text:
I use milk and cream in place of the milk and oil. The waffles are much better, and even healthier.

    2 eggs
    2 cups all-purpose flour
    1 cup milk
    1 cup heavy cream
    1 tablespoon white sugar
    4 teaspoons baking powder
    1/4 teaspoon salt
    1/2 teaspoon vanilla extract

text:
I try a different recipe everytime I make waffles. Obviously I don't make them that often but everytime I plan on making them, I have to run to the market to get buttermilk, active yeast, and other ingredients that I don't have normally sitting at home. I'm never doing that again and I'm never finding a new recipe. Waffles turned up fluffy and light, unlike the other waffle recipes I've tried.
I accidentally dumped some all spice in the mix thinking it was cinnamon and it actually still turned out pretty good. I would recommend this to anyone. Simple and great recipe!

My kids are doing the "30 hour famine" tomorrow and need a BIG breakfast, before 6am!  Of course, they requested waffles, and I wasnt looking forward to getting up in the morning to make them.  It was the part in the description about leaving the batter in the fridge that convinced me to try it.  I have a great recipe that I usually make that requires beating whites separately and melting butter.  I didnt want the hastle, and I can say, if these are half as good in the morning as the sample that we tasted tonight, I will never bother with the other recipe again!!  Thanks!

This was a very simple recipe.  The 1st time I made it I made it exactly as directed.  Turned out great.  The 2nd time I used 1 cup WW flour and 1 cup AP flour.  It still turned out great.  The 3rd time I made it I used 1 cup ww flour and 1 cup ap flour, doubled the vanilla, added a touch more sugar and added cinnamon. It was great.   This is a very good recipe no matter how you make it!!

text:
I made these with the following variations, in order to make sweet potato waffles: 
Reduce milk to 1 1/2 cups, add 3/4 cup Bruce's sweet potato pie filling, substitute dark brown sugar for the white sugar, and separate egg whites and whip them, then fold them in at the last minute.
They were yummy!

text:
VERY pleased with this recipe!  Used buttermilk instead of regular milk, and like others suggested used a tad more white sugar, and whipped egg whites separately and folded in at the end.  Crispy outside, light fluffy and delicious inside. I was also impressed with how crispy they stayed even after being removed from the waffle.  These were made yesterday, and today we put the leftovers in the toaster and they were still surprising delicious and crisp.  Served with Blueberry Maple Butter (maple syrup + butter + fresh blueberries. )  KEEPER recipe...Thanks for submitting!

text:
I don't separate the egg whites (because that would then be the extra step I was avoiding - hence trying this recipe!) but rather beat the eggs a long time - until they get all frothy. 

I also toss in chocolate chips and the result is a great dessert that my son asks for every day! Best waffle recipe I have found! (hint about choc chips: I put them in a food processor to make smaller bits so there is more chocolate spread throughout the waffle)

country:

text:
Decent basic light/crispy waffle recipe.  I did double the sugar and vanilla, and added 1t cinnamon as other reviewers suggested.  Still, the waffles were fairly bland and derive most of their flavor from the butter/syrup/toppings--but a basic recipe is what I was looking for.   I used an Oster round waffle maker and just over 3/4c of batter was the perfect amount per waffle.  I cooked them for 4 mins on medium high heat after preheating the waffle iron for 5 mins or so.  Texture was great--very light.

text:
This recipe was really good! I only made half of it, put in a spoonful of sugar (I only used half the recipe), substituted the oil for applesauce, and I didn't have vanilla so I left that out. I was very pleased with the results. The pancakes had no sticking problems to the waffle iron (with a little non-stick spray) and could crisp up nicely if you liked them that way. For half the recipe I thought a spoonful (it was medium-large) was enough flavor and sweetness.. especially when you have syrup, fresh peaches, and whipped cream on top! I was very happy!

text:
I just got my new Cuisinart Professional Waffle Maker and was looking for a good waffle recipe that was easier than the ones that came in the instruction manual (they all had yeast!?!) So I tried this one after reading some of the reviews.  I beat the egg whites seperately and added more sugar and vanilla as per some reviews as these are mainly to please the kids.  Today I also added a bit of cinammon to the mix.  It makes a waffle with a really nice texture.  Crisp on the outside and soft and fluffy on the inside.  The kids are really impressed and suggested to me that we put portions in the fridge so they can cook their own on school mornings.

text:
This is an easy, always-turns-out-perfect waffle recipe.  I make them gluten-free with Bob's Red Mill All-Purpose Gluten Free Flour and I add one teaspoon of xanthan gum.  I also substitute 1/4 cup melted butter for 1/4 cup of the oil and 1 cup of buttermilk for part of the milk just for fun.  I make these waffles almost weekly and I freeze leftovers to toast later.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made these with 2/3 C almond flour and the rest all-purpose gluten free flour.  I also substituted almond milk for the dairy and honey for the sugar.  I didn't have vanilla extract.  The flavor of these waffles is pretty bland, but I think that's the way it's supposed to be!  But, oh man, the texture is just awesome.  So crispy and light, and I didn't bother beating the eggs separately.  I just mixed all of the liquids together at once.  I don't get much steam from my waffle iron, but I found that 9 minutes is about how long it took to bring these to a golden brown.  These waffles reheat extremely well in the toaster oven.

text:
Absolutely delicious! To make it easier I measured milk in a large 2 cup measuring cup, added egg yolks, vanilla & oil. Whisked vigorously.  Put my sifter on top of my large 8 cup measuring bowl.  Sifted dry ingredients  then whisked in milk mixture till smooth.  Whipped egg whites till stiff then folded into batter.  I did double the sugar and vanilla like previous reviews. They were just perfect!  Thanks for the recipe.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is certainly an improvement over the recipe that came with my waffle maker. I still found it to be a little bland. I used almost twice the vanilla, about ¼ c of sugar, and some almond extract for flavor. If I made this again I might try a little citrus zest to kick it up next time too. My husband and I used quite a bit of syrup and my son only ate about half of his.   Whipping up the egg whites and folding them into the batter does make a huge difference. The batter will be lighter and your waffle more fluffy.   An ok recipe as a base to play with, but fairly flavorless on its own.

country:

text:
This is hands down the BEST waffle recipe I have ever made! I was shocked at how fluffy and light they turned out to be and was even more amazed at the taste. I am pretty sure I've made this recipe 5 times in the last 2 weeks! This morning we realized we didn't have any vegetable oil so we substituted melted margarine. I was disappointed but my husband said "with a waffle recipe as delicious as this one it can afford to lose a little ingredient-wise and will still be great" and he was right! This is definitely a staple breakfast for us! To the people who made this and it didn't turn out...I honestly don't know what you did. Maybe you replaced the baking powder with baking soda or something? I am not sure how you could screw this up if you follow the directions!  Thanks, OneShyOfABunch!

country:
None
text:
Major Revision:  I separated the eggs and whipped the egg whites into firm peaks. In a separate bowl I blended all of the ingredients (yes, the egg yolks too).  I added a teaspoon more vanilla extract and 1/2 tablespoon of sugar to the recipe. Then I folded the whites into the batter at the very last minute.  I used a belgian waffle iron.  So my waffles were crisp on the outside, but fluffy and moist in the middle.

text:
super light and airy and fully says my hubby. This is the second time I've made a batch. This is what I did different though: 1) Blend eggs with milk with my Magic Bullet; 2) double the vanilla; 3) half the sugar and evoo (instead of veggie oil); and 4) added a touch of nutmeg.  I think using the Magic Bullet for the eggs and milk really made the difference. Last time, I followed someone else's recommendation to whip the egg whites separately from yolks and then folded it in. This time it was even fluffier than the last. :)

text:
This is excellent with a few tweaks.  Like others I doubled the vanilla and sugar and added 1/4tsp cinnamon.  Also, I listened to what others said, and separating the egg whites and making beating them fluffy, then adding them in the end is genius!  the first time I made these I didn't do that and they didn't rise enough to meet the other side of the waffle iron.  With the fluffy egg whites added they fluff right up!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent waffle recipe. Recommend separating the eggs; whipping the egg whites until stiff peaks form; using a whisk to mix the egg yolks, milk, oil and vanilla; sifting together the dry ingredients and mixing them into the wet ingredients with the whisk; then folding the egg whites into the batter with a spatula, leaving a few fluffs of whites in tact. I used 1 1/8c. of batter for each waffle in my Presto Flip Side waffle maker, and the recipe yielded 4 1/2, 7-inch waffles.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
VEGAN FRIENDLY! YEAH!  Not nearly a vegan, but I was craving waffles so bad and my new iron was hot, so I made and ate 4 waffles before adding egg and they were good. (It wasn't just the hunger.) For the vegan add about 2-3 more tablespoons of "milk" and a 1/4 tsp of baking soda should be added by everyone.  The sodium from the baking soda will permeate the batter more effectively than salt alone.  I added 3 more tbsps of sugar bringing the total to 1/4 c of sugar and a whole tsp of vanilla.  Overall, great texture and delicious prepared in advance and toasted the next morning. It lost a star b/c the flavor needed so much tweeking.  Everything else was great.

text:
This is the best waffle recipe I have found, and I have tried several different waffle recipes. The main reason why I love this recipe so much is because it doesn't have a huge amount of butter in it. Every waffle recipe I have made asks for a tone of butter. The Joy of Cooking cook book asks for 16 tablespoons of butter in their recipe (yowza!), so I am very pleased to find a recipe that tastes great, is fluffy yet firm, and doesn't make me gain five pounds after eating my breakfast.
Review:

5

I made these this morning for "Waffle Wednesday." I've only made Bisquick's waffles, but since I'm getting away from using it, chose this recipe. I'm sorry to say that I was disappointed in this recipe. The one change I made was increasing the vanilla to 1tsp, but these were rather bland. The waffles also became soggy really fast. I was shocked at the amount of oil called for, as half a cup seems like a lot IMO. Will continue my search...

Display Name:
STARLENEDOE

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I have tried this recipe both as it is written and with others modifications. It's definitely better with the modifications. I did this as advised by other raters: doubled sugar and vanilla, added 1/2 tsp cinnamon (added flavor, not overpowering) and brown sugar, reduced oil to 1/4 cup and beat egg whites separate from the yolks. Difference with the mods: lighter, fluffier and more taste! Less dense and hard. YUMMY! Now is a keeper!
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2009-12-26T16:34:40.213
helpfulCount:
0

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was great. The only reason I gave it 4 stars was because I did change it. I separated the egg whites and set them aside. Mixed the egg yokes with the wet ingredients. Then mixed the dry ingredents(I used white wheat flour) and added 1/2 teaspoon of pumkin spice.  Next I beat the egg whites to a peak and folded them into the batter.  This makes them come out crips. Cook for 7 to 8 minutes. Left overs we freeze and my kids love putting them into the toaster through out the week.  They also love it when I cook some rasins into them.  I at least make them once a week.

text:
They way I made these turned out great.  I made these into all healthy waffles.  I used King Arthur's Whole Wheat Flour,  Organic Vanilla Soy Milk ( can use the low fat kind, although it's already low in fat!), I used Splenda and doubled it as suggested by others. Instead of oil I used a 4 oz jar of baby food.  I didn't have applesauce like others suggested so I looked for a baby food applesauce and only found "Apples & Peaches" but it worked just the same!  Then to top the waffles I used Smart Balance Omega with Extra Virgin Olive Oil Butter Spread & Maple Grove Farms Sugar Free Syrup.  These tasted pretty much like a regular waffle only WAY healthy.  Plus with all the fiber you will feel full after one and stay full for a good part of the day!!

A simple, yet good waffle recipe.  The only thing I change is to separate the egg whites, whip until stiff peaks form, then fold them in at the end.  It makes the waffles so much fluffier!  We also love to add chocolate chips.  Double the sugar and vanilla for a sweeter, richer waffle.  Yummy!!

userID:
1912649
Display Name:
lace
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/140002.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was very good! I followed the suggestions of others by doubling the vanilla, doubling the sugar, adding 1/2 tsp cinnamon, and separating the eggs. I whisked the egg whites until light and fluffy and folded in last. I also used a hand mixer. The batter seemed thinner than a typical box mix, possibly b/c of the hand mixer. May work just as well using a whisk. The recipe will make at least 5 full size waffles and probably 6 if none of it ran over the sides (thin batter). The result was light and fluffy pancakes! They tasted very good and my friend said they were "the best waffles he ever had." I definitely think the cinnamon and vanilla are the key ingredients. I also noticed that the waffles are crispier if you don't spray the iron with cooking spray. If you like softer waffles, spray it every other waffle made. I also added chocolate chips to a few - Yum! Batter works great stored over night as well.

This was my first time making waffles from scratch so I wanted just an easy recipe to follow.  This was not only easy to follow, but my waffles turned out wonderfully (minus my first mistake of putting too much batter into my waffle iron!).  I have a thing for cinnamon and vanilla so I ended up putting in a whole lot more vanilla than called for.  I also didn't separate the eggs like what some people had suggested and my waffles still turned out amazing!  I will be making this again in the future as it makes 8 large waffles.

text:
I substituted half the oil with applesauce, doubled the vanilla, and used brown sugar instead of white. As other reviewers have recommended, I beat the egg whites separately and folded them into the batter at the end. The waffles were excellent: light and fluffy on the inside and perfectly crisp on the outside. They tasted were delicious and so easy to make. Next time, I plan on using whole wheat flour and flax seed instead of white flour. I will never use waffle mix again!

This recipe reminds me of the waffles that my grandmother made for me as a child.  The only reason for the 4 stars rather than 5 is that like other reviews, I doubled the amount of sugar and vanilla and I always seperate my eggs and beat my egg whites until stiff and fold them into the batter before pouring into waffle iron.  There is only my husband and I so I bake all of the waffles and freeze the remainder.  I toast them in toaster at medium dark.  They are as crispy on the outside and tender on the inside as the day I made them.  Great recipe

text:
I first tried this recipe as written, but have tweaked it to be more to our liking.  Use double the salt and sugar, only 1 1/2 cups milk and bump up the flour to 2 1/4 cups so the batter is thicker.  My boyfriend prefers half a teaspoon of ground cinnamon in the batter.  I've been making these waffles every Sunday for a month now and we love them!

Loved the basis of this recipe. Made a few changes. Double the amount of sugar and vanilla, and change from 1 3/4 c milk to => 3/4 c buttermilk, 1 c milk. Also, separate egg white and beat until peaks form.  Go ahead and add yolks to main mixture. Fold in egg whites. Wonderful! I make these especially for Christmas morning.

country:
None
text:
We ran out of our boxed waffle/pancake mix this morning, so I decided to try something different.  This mix was pretty good, but I wouldn't say it was awesome.  I added 2 tablespoons of extra flour (the batter was originally too thin IMO), and an extra tablespoon of sugar, as well as extra vanilla extract.  I like my waffles sweet, not savory, which is why the sugar and vanilla were doubled.  Crunchy on the outside, soft and warm on the inside.  This mix made six perfect waffles, and I'm going to freeze half of them for later.  Yum!

I made these waffles this morning with a few changes, and they were wonderful. They turned out so light and airy! I used 1/2 cup whole wheat flour and then 1 and 1/2 cups of unbleached white flour. I separated the eggs. Then beat the whites until soft peaks formed. I then folded them in at the end. I also doubled the amount of vanilla to 1 teaspoon, and added 1/2 teaspoon of cinnamon. I have 6 kiddos and these were a huge hit. I hope you try it with the adjustments!

text:
I have given this waffle recipe a 5 star rating based on, this is the very first waffle recipe that I have ever made in my waffle maker that has worked out. The only thing I would change as others have noted here are I would increase the sugar to 2 1/2 TBS and the vanilla 1 1/2 time. Make sure you beat the eggs until they are very fluffy. This makes the difference of perfect or not perfect waffles. Also on the advice of anothr waffle review, I waited until the steam stopped pluming on the sides to dictate when the waffles are done. PERFECTION. Thanks for a great recipe.

This was my first attempt making waffles from scratch rather than using a commercial mix. Easy recipe to follow and assemble. I whisked wet ingredients and sifted in dry. I added approx. 1 TBSP more sugar and 1/2 tsp cinnamon. I used a 1/3 measure (plus a bit more) to fill my iron. I found them light and fluffy, but I missed the crispness of the commercial mix. text:
I have a waffle iron that must be 55+years old with iron waffle/sandwich changeable grids which all my family covets and I refuse to give up.  This recipe is a superior one but I made some changes.  I used part melted butter with the oil, used Splenda + 1 T for the sugar, 1 egg + 1 egg equivalent Egg Beaters for the 2 eggs, 1t. ground ginger.  The result was delicious and lower in calories than the original.  Highly recommend this to any waffle enthusiast!

text:
I make this recipe often, and it always turns out very well. I make it vegan by substituting two tablespoons ground flax seed and six tablespoons water for the eggs and soymilk. (I usually up the soymilk to two cups.) Generally I substitute whole wheat flour for white flour. I also add double the sugar called for and a generous dash of cinnamon. A great way to start the morning!
